text: The plant is massive, grime-streaked, squatting in the va under five massive stacks, each one trailing a black ribb across the winter sky. Fires can be seen flickering throu the windows and long flames weave and dance from the tops guyed metal flues. Steam rises in clouds from vents and chimneys and the sound of it all -- the hissing, the clanging, the rumbling, the shrieking -- comes faintly, m by the falling snow. In the foreground is a street -- COLUMBINE STREET -- whic inhabits the bottom of a narrow ravine and plunges direct down the hillside, straight at the mill. Columbine is a s looking street, a grim-looking street, a street hanging o the skin of its teeth. Dilapidated stores hug the narrow sidewalks. Battered signs squeak in the wind. Sandwiched between the stores and scattered on twisting roads along hillside are narrow Victorian houses. These houses, which to three stories or more in height, all seem on the verge toppling over, and undoubtedly would, except that they ar all connected one to another by a mad arrangement of util lines which cross and re-cross between them with occasion aid from a leaning pole. MUSIC COMES UP -- dissonant, rather frightening music -- we watch a car come charging up through the slush on Columbine Street. As it nears CAMERA the car falters on t slippery grade and slides out of sight. A figure appears, huddled against the driving snow. The figure disappears A

head_text.subj: CAMERA HOLDS ON THE STEEL MILL AT THE END OF THE EMPTY

text: A white-hot ingot shoots out of an ejecting mechanism and comes ripping down a track. Another ingot follows it, and another and another and another. The ingots are huge, trembling with heat, and they come on with a terrifying rumble.

UNDER CREDITS we see STEELWORKERS catching the ingots wit tongs and deftly swinging them into troughs. The STEELWOR wear leather aprons and are stripped to the waist. Warped heat waves and glistening with sweat they seem like figur in some hellish ballet. Since they all wear goggles it is hard to distinguish between them, but there are three, wh are young, who seem to work with particular grace. These NICK, SAL and MERLE. CREDITS END. CAMERA CLOSES ON NICK, SAL AND MERLE. The no is deafening, the heat is unbelievable and the ingots com with murderous speed. Taking advantage of a slight pause MERLE jabs NICK and they both make cuckold's horns at SAL SAL blushes and waves them off with his hand. MERLE and N make the horns again and now SAL puts both hands on his h gives a thin smile and studies the corner of the shed. ME and NICK begin laughing. SAL can't hold out and he starts laughing too, but now the ingots begin roaring down the t again and they all grab their tongs.

A very old PRIEST is making preparations for a wedding ceremony. SAL'S MOTHER hovers around him as he unlocks a cabinet and takes out white tapers and a golden crown whi will be used in the service. The PRIEST moves with agoniz slowness and SAL's MOTHER is in the midst of a bad case o nerves.
It's all ready? Everything's ready?
Yes.
Are you sure everything's ready? Are you positive?
Everything. Yes.
It would snow... Everything's going to slip. Everything's going to slide... All the cars are going to crash! SAL'S MOTHER puts her hand to her mouth and bursts into tears.
I can't believe this... My own little boy... with a stranger! The PRIEST smiles. He takes SAL'S MOTHER in his arms and comforts her.

Another car lunges up the hill, gets about halfway and sl back. As the car disappears, the door to one of the house bursts open and a group of giggling BRIDESMAIDS begin scampering across the street. They have all been working their dresses, which are not completely finished, and the all carry ribbons and scissors and pieces of material. As they make their way to the other side of the street they wave away the snowflakes and grab each other for support. of the BRIDESMAIDS loses her dress entirely and with ever laughing she rushes back to retrieve it in her slip. When garment is repossessed a door comes open and the BRIDESMA disappear inside. CAMERA HOLDS ON COLUMBINE STREET. The snow slants across little stores and piles on the gables of the tipsy little houses. Another car appears, lunges at the hill and slide back. Suddenly the door to the bakery comes open and a gr of OLDER WOMEN emerge carrying a huge wedding cake with a miniature bride and groom standing on the top. The WOMEN all in their fifties and bundled in boots and dark overco They begin moving slowly up the street, in the driving sn with the great white cake held firmly between them.

The time clocks are lined against both walls. As a whistl screams to mark the end of the shift thousands of men beg checking out. NICK, SAL and MERLE are right up in the fro ranks and once they have clocked their cards they gather together along the wall.
Where's Vince?
There's Albert!  (calls) Hey, Albert!!! ALBERT -- six and a half feet tall and built like an ox - changes course and plows across the river of homeward-bou STEELWORKERS.
How you feelin', Sal?
I feel okay.
Feeling hot?
(arm around SAL) Humper's ready. Old humper's hotter'n damn hell!
There's Vince!
(calling) Vince!... Over here! Vince!
Get him, Albert. Get Vince!
I'll get him. ALBERT wades back into the stream of STEELWORKERS, grabs VINCE and they all push out together.

The snow is still falling. It covers the ground. It cover the acres of parked cars. It swirls and tosses and blows. the five friends come bursting out of a side exit they al stop dead in their tracks.
Snow... Holy shit, snow! SAL gives a look at the others. Something is going on. VI is so excited he begins hopping around.
... Do you know what this means? Do you guys realize exactly what this means? They all know. They all know damn well. MERLE and NICK exchange looks. ALBERT chortles.
What are you guys...? Are you guys going hunting? The others nod, shrug, shuffle their feet. They are all a little embarrassed.
Not tonight?... You're not driving up tonight?
As soon as you're hitched, Sal. First we get you hitched.
(envious) You guys are crazy. You know that? I mean you guys are really nuts.
He's getting married... and we're nuts!
(puts his arm around SAL) It's all right. Hey, it's all right. We'll be right here, right with you. A look at the others...
Won't we? Right? Am I right?
Right.
Damn right!
What do you think, Sal? Jesus, you think we'd miss this? Now SAL is embarrassed. He makes a gesture with his hand.
(with a laugh) C'mon. C'mon you guys! They all start into the swirling snow. NICK with an arm around SAL.
And we want you to know, Sal, that any help you might need--
Yeah, Sal--
Willing fingers--
Extra feet!

The place is large and drafty and rundown. A huge America flag hangs from the middle of the ceiling. Under it WOMEN laying white table cloths on trestle tables. Off to one s a half dozen OLD MEN wearing VFW hats are Scotch-taping p ribbons to the brick wall. Two OLD MEN are on stepladders two more are bracing the ladders and the operation is und the direction of a pair of World War I VETS standing side side. Their hands tremble. Their four eyes loom huge behi corrective lenses.
Up I would say... What would you say?
Up.
(signals) Up ribbon! One end of the ribbon is moved up. The two VETS study it.
Down I would say... What would you say?
Down.

(signals) Down ribbon! Suddenly there is a commotion. The WOMEN who are setting the tables all rush to the door as the OLDER WOMEN come i with the wedding cake. The OLDER WOMEN look half-frozen a as they move toward a table the cake receives a great cho of Uhh's and Ahh's. Suddenly one of the OLDER WOMEN collapses. Friends rush to her aid, seat her in a chair a give her wine. The WOMAN takes the glass, tosses it off i one swallow and grins. EVERYONE laughs.
A big, battered old shark-finned black Cadillac approache coming fast.
NICK, SAL, MERLE, VINCE and ALBERT are all laughing. NICK at the wheel.
Hit it, Nick!
Go Nick! Hit it, baby!!!
The car bangs over potholes and slams into the grade. We watch as it reaches the half-way point, then the three quarter mark...
NICK bends forward over the wheel, peering out through th slapping wipers.
(chanting) Do it, Nick! Do it! Go Nick, Go! Do it! Do it, Nick! Go! The car fishtails, loses speed... to a creep.
Back! All hands to the rear! ALBERT and MERLE, who are sitting in front, immediately t themselves into the back seat on top of SAL and VINCE.
Easy... 'At's it, easy! Easy, Nick... Easy!
The Cadillac inches up the last ten feet, gains level gro and skids to a stop. From inside comes a MUTED CHEER.
ANGELA is dressed in her white bridal gown and veil. She plump, pretty, with a solemn, round face and big brown ey ANGELA leans forward into a mirror.
(sincerely) I do. A pause. ANGELA scowls and tries it again.
(heartfelt) I do. ANGELA tries it a few more times. It sounds worse and wor

I do, I do, I do!!! ANGELA stares at herself. Now she looks desperate and unrelievedly forlorn. Bursting into tears she throws hers on the bed. Someone has slipped a photograph under the pillow. The photograph is face down and as ANGELA pulls i out she sees that something is written on the back:
(reading, slow) "This is it -- more or less... Love, Mom." ANGELA frowns, turns the photograph over. It is a picture Michaelangelo's "David". ANGELA stares at the figure for long, long moment...
Oh, wow.

The place is packed with boisterous STEELWORKERS drinking boilermakers. Deerheads are mounted in a long row over th bar, and hand-painted murals decorate the walls. The mura depict hunting scenes and display an eerie tone -- at onc comical and frightening -- as if the animals held some se from the hunters, some power beyond their own. JOHN bangs out from behind the bar with a tray of beer. A the same moment SAL comes in with NICK, MERLE, ALBERT and VINCE. JOHN, who is a great bear of a youth, puts down hi tray, wraps his arms around SAL and begins jumping him ar the floor, grinning ear to ear. The STEELWORKERS turn, de their places and swarm around SAL, joking and shouting congratulations.

LINDA is thin -- a skinny slip of a thing with a haunting lovely face. Wearing her bridesmaid's dress she stands al in the kitchen, staring at the ceiling. Thumping noises a coming from the room above. The thumping gets louder. There is a crash, then another crash, as if furniture wer being thrown around. A MAN'S VOICE begins cursing and the is more thumping and crashing. Suddenly there is a thud.. and then silence. LINDA bites her lip. She crosses to the stove, ladles ste into a bowl, butters bread, pours a cup of tea and puts i all on a tray.

The room is a wreck of broken furniture. Chairs are turne over, lamps are smashed and the pictures hang cockeyed on wall. In the middle of the room, face down on the floor, LINDA'S FATHER. His coat is torn, one shoe is missing and holds a half-empty bottle in his hand. Behind him, throug the open window, snow is blowing in. LINDA comes in with the tray. She stands for a moment expressionless, looking down at her father. Then she sets tray on the bureau and kneels beside him.
Daddy?

(mumbles) Go... fucking hell! LINDA reaches down, takes her FATHER by the shoulder and rolls him over. It takes some effort and the face that co up is gray, unshaven and implacably bitter. Saliva dribbl from his mouth, there is a cut with the stitches still in seaming his forehead and as LINDA looks at him he begins cursing again.

Fucking shit... all around, like a sea! Like an ocean! LINDA gets up and closes the window. She comes back, gets down on the floor beside her father and pushes him toward bed. Then, hiking up her bridesmaid's dress, she takes hi the shoulders again and heaves him onto the coverlet. The effort is almost too much for her. Tears begin to burn in eyes, but when he slips back she tries again. The father groans, begins to mumble, and then, when she almost has h on the bed, he suddenly lifts his hand, catches her full the face and pushes her violently across the room. LINDA crashes backwards over a fallen chair and smashes i the wall. As she gets to her feet her father advances on
Fucking bitch... All bitches! He swings, catches her in the face again, hard.
Daddy...! Daddy, it's me!
Hate 'em. Fucking bitches! LINDA'S FATHER swings at her again, loses his balance and falls on the floor. LINDA stands looking at him, holding jaw. She is crying. Tears are streaming down her face.
Seven MUSICIANS, carrying their instruments, file silentl through the falling snow.

The WOMEN are all gathered, some fifteen or twenty, rangi from grandmothers to young wives. About half of them wiel rolling pins or heavy pans. As the last reinforcements ar -- TWO HEFTY LADIES WITH TRUNCHEONS -- a roar of laughter comes from inside.

NICK, SAL, MERLE, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN are dancing. The MUSIC is at top volume and the smoke is thick enough to c with a knife. Suddenly, from the back, comes a CHORUS OF SCREECHES AND FEMALE RECRIMINATIONS. The door to the alle bursts open and the HEFTY LADIES WITH TRUNCHEONS appear. STEELWORKERS take one look, gulp their drinks, grab their heads in their hands and rush for the front door.

The STEELWORKERS stream into the snow with the WOMEN clos behind. Several blows are delivered and the howls of complaint are met with angry commands to hurry and get dressed for Sal's wedding. CAMERA CLOSES ON SAL, who emerges with NICK and MERLE. Th snow hits him a sobering blow and he comes to a stop.
Boy, this is it. This is really it... I mean... here I go. SAL'S MOTHER hurries out of the alley. She is crying.
My beautiful boy! My angel... who is leaving his own mother. She throws herself in SAL's arms, sobbing.
Momma...
So cold is your heart to leave your own mother?
Momma, I'll be right upstairs. SAL throws a look to NICK and MERLE. They gesture with sympathy and study the snow flakes.
So cruel is your heart? Is your heart so uncaring?
(a litany now) One flight, Momma. It's one flight.

The trailer is a dented two-tone pink and cream job which looks as if it had been purchased third-hand off a construction site. It stands on cinder blocks in a small which has been cut out of the side of the hill. A wrecked school bus decorates it to the right. On the left is a ba branched tree. NICK's black Cadillac is parked in front a light shows from inside the trailer. CAMERA PICKS UP MERLE who is strolling toward the trailer whistling through his teeth. He is wearing his tuxedo and carries a knapsack and a deer rifle. He mounts the cinder block steps and pounds on the trailer door. NICK opens th door and waves him in.

The place is cramped, littered with camping paraphernalia deer head is mounted above the sink and NICK, who is half into his tuxedo, is applying waterproofing to a pair of h boots. MERLE smiles, throws his kit on the stove and sits
(indicates the waterproofing) You should have put that on last night.
I know.
That way it sets.
Yeah. Pause.
I just wait. You know?
Huh?
I just wait. For this... It's what I wait for... I wait all year.
So do I.
(sharp) You do?
(nods) Yeah. NICK grins, takes down his rifle and begins wiping the oi off it.
You think about it?
Yeah.
So do I. (watches Nick for a minute) I want to be ready... You have to be ready... It has to be there, in your mind.
The shot?
Fucking A.
I don't think about the shot that much.
(firmly) You have to think about the shot. It's the shot. The shot's it.
(uncertain) Yeah... I guess.
(studies him) What do you think about?

I don't know... I guess I think about the deer... Being out, maybe. I don't know. I think about it all. Hell, I like the trees, you know? I like the ways the trees are, all the different ways the trees are too.
(with a glance to the window) I'll tell you something, Nick. I wouldn't hunt with anyone but you. I won't hunt with a yo-yo.
(laughs) Yo-yo! Who's a yo-yo?

Who's a yo-yo...? Who do you think's a yo-yo! They're all yo yo's. I mean they're all great guys, for Christ's sake, but... The point is, Nick, without you I'd hunt alone. Seriously. I would. That's what I'd do.
(laughs) You're a fucking nut. You know that, Merle? You're a fucking maniac!

Yeah. (he grins) When it comes to hunting, that's true. Cursing and banging from outside. NICK opens the door. JO and ALBERT, both in tuxedoes and loaded down with gear, a pounding on the trunk of the Cadillac, trying to get it o NICK and MERLE go out.
Albert! For Christ's sake... John! Wait a minute, you guys!
It won't open.
You gotta hit it here. Here, Albert, not there.
Where should I hit it? Just show me where I should hit it.
Here. Hit it here. ALBERT hits the trunk in the indicated spot and the lid s open.
Hey, that's neat. NICK nods.
That's new, isn't it?
Couple of weeks... Listen --

I love this car. Some cars sit, you know? This car, a car like this... grows. I mean you never know, with a car like this, where this car has been. VINCE comes up, also in tuxedo, and dragging a totally disorganized clutter of hunting gear behind him.
Hey, guys...

Shhh! Albert's gonna hump the Coup de Ville. ALBERT looks around at his friends. He surveys the back e of the Cadillac with simian pride. Then he expands his ch thumps on it with both fists and yodels out a magnificent mile-carrying Tarzan call. As the echo of it comes back t church bell begins ringing down the street and a group of excited BRIDESMAIDS come, hurrying up.
Albert, what are you doing!
Hurry up, you guys!
Who's got their carnations?
Here. They're right here.
Look at you! You're all a mess!
Put on their carnations!

Who's got a pin? As the BRIDESMAIDS begin straightening ties and putting o carnations, NICK hears someone call his name. He turns to find LINDA standing beside the trailer where she can't be seen. She looks pale and very frightened and she holds a small suitcase in her hand.
(crosses) Linda...
Hi. (forces a smile) Nick, your shoes are soaking.
Linda, what's the matter?
(tries to toss it off) Oh... You know... She fights against it but the tears begin to come. NICK l around, pulls her inside the trailer.
NICK clears a place on the couch. LINDA sits, holding her suitcase in her lap.
(with great effort) I was just wondering... Nick... You're going hunting... If I could use this place to stay, because...
Sure. Are you kidding? Sure.
I'd want to pay you... and I was thinking --
(kneels in front of her) Linda... Hey, Linda...
I would want to pay you, Nick... and I was thinking --
Linda, Linda...!
(very small, looking into his eyes) What?
Will you marry me?
(after a long, long moment) Okay.
Would you? LINDA nods - a solemn nod.
You would? LINDA's lip begins to tremble. Tears stand in her eyes an she gives a little toss of her head.
Who else, dummy? NICK stares at her. He can still hardly believe it.
This is terrific...! This is really terrific! LINDA nods. She is suddenly excited, suddenly radiantly happy. She takes the suitcase off her lap and throws hers in NICK's arms.
I don't know what we've been waiting for!
(eyes closed, loving him) I don't know! I don't know either!
SAL and ANGELA stand facing each other as the PRIEST read the Holy Sacrament of Marriage.

"Blessed be the Kingdom... now and forever unto Ages and Ages... As the PRIEST continues with the Holy Sacrament CAMERA PI UP FACES IN THE CONGREGATION. We see SAL'S FAMILY. We see ANGELA'S FAMILY. We see the VETS from the V.F.W. Post. We the STEELWORKERS from the bar and the WIVES and MOTHERS w chased them home to change. They are hard faces -- workin class faces -- but we sense a fortitude among the congregation, a community of both heart and spirit. CAMERA PICKS UP NICK, MERLE, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN stand in a row opposite the BRIDESMAIDS. The guys all look slig disheveled. Their tuxedos are all too small and their sho are soaking wet from walking in the snow. NICK catches LINDA's eye and they hold each other across intervening space like two children who are amazed. The PRIEST hands white tapers to the bride and groom. CAM CLOSES SLOWLY ON THE PRIEST. The man is impressive -- gen yet full of power. The PRIEST lights the tapers -- first ANGELA's, then SAL's -- and looks out across the assemble congregation.
"For everyone that does evil hates the light, and does not come to the light, lest his deeds will be reproved."
Save for a lone figure trudging home, the street is deser left to the gently falling snow. In the background the massive silhouette of the steel mill is plainly visible, with fire.
NICK, MERLE, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN join with the BRIDESM to assist the PRIEST in the crowning of SAL and ANGELA. The PRIEST crowns SAL first.
"The servant of God, Sal, is crowned for the servant of God Angela, in the Name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost. Amen." Now ANGELA is crowned.

"The servant of God, Angela, is crowned for the servant of God, Sal, in the Name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost. Amen." Guiding the couple by their joined hands the PRIEST leads and ANGELA around the analoy. The movement is very precis very formal, a circling to represent eternity.

The Band is going full blast and the whirling COUPLES, yo and old, are laughing. We see SAL and ANGELA, NICK and LINDA, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN. The only one of the group not dancing is MERLE. MER is drinking, standing alone on the side of the floor chug beer in tense, rapid-fire gulps. We sense immediately tha feels out of place, at a loss to join spontaneously in th spirit of the party. MERLE finishes the beer, crumples th can and starts on another. As he picks up the second can notices that a SAD-LOOKING GIRL is sitting against the wa behind him, waiting for someone to ask her to dance. The LOOKING GIRL gives MERLE a smile. MERLE pretends not to s and moves behind a post.

The wedding cake that was carried in earlier has now been attacked from all sides, but the miniature bride and groo are still standing in the middle. Unnoticed by each other SAL'S MOTHER and ANGELA'S MOTHER eye the little figures. women are in rather teary condition and begin moving towa the cake. Suddenly, as the CROWD shifts, they encounter e other face to face. Smiles are exchanged -- strained smil which get stretched and stretched and stretched. Then, in unison, they desert the smiling and remove their respecti offspring from the cake. SAL'S MOTHER looks down at her s coated groom and ANGELA'S MOTHER looks down at her sugar coated bride. Then they eye each other, burst into tears throw themselves in each other's arms, moaning and sobbin
Another COUPLE tries to enter the rack. It is pretty full They finally find an empty place and squeeze in.
NICK comes off the floor with LINDA and throws an arm aro MERLE.
Sit with Linda, man, will ya?... Give her a beer. (to Linda with great solicitude) Would you like a beer?
(puzzled) Sure.
What kind of beer would you like?
(laughing) I don't know.

(to Merle) Give her Miller's. Miller's High Life. NICK takes off. LINDA sits down at a table and MERLE goes the cooler to get a Miller's. He gropes around in the tub finds one and pops the tab. Suddenly he notices that NICK crossed to the SAD-LOOKING GIRL by the wall. He has stopp in front of her and is asking her something. The SAD-LOOK GIRL gives a blush, gets out of her chair and NICK takes in his arms and begins to dance. The SAD-LOOKING GIRL loo transformed. She begins chattering and laughing. MERLE crosses back to LINDA and gives her the beer. As he pulls up a chair to sit down beside her he stumbles and nearly loses his balance. He is very drunk.
Sorry.
(laughs) It's okay, Merle. NICK swings by with the SAD-LOOKING GIRL and waves.
(catching Linda's expression) I guess you like Nick.
(nods) Yes. MERLE doesn't say anything for a moment. He seems to be trying to contain a floodtide of emotion.
Fuckin' Nick...  (clears his throat) Fuckin' Nick... gives.  (he nods, bangs his fist on the table) Gives. Fuckin' Nick gives.

The rack is still jammed with COUPLES but the laughing an giggling has now given way to the sound of heavy breathin and low moans. What light there is comes from the colored glass ball revolving above the dance floor, where the MUSIC is now playing sweet and low. The front door comes open and a U.S. Army SERGEANT steps the darkened hallway. The man wears his dress green unifo On his chest is a row of battle ribbons and his shoes are brightly polished.
Pow! The SERGEANT gives a beery chuckle and moves toward the d floor.
The SERGEANT passes between groups of celebrating GUESTS, plucks a beer from one of the coolers and sits down alone the end of one of the white trestle tables.
ALBERT gives his Tarzan cry, suddenly picks his GIRL off feet and marches around holding her above his head.
Albert, what are you doing... Albert!
VINCE and JOHN are standing together. VINCE is going bana because his girl, MARSHA, is dancing too close to FRED.
Look at that, see... Watch. Wait a minute, watch. There! D'j'u see that? D'j'u see the way he... You know what that guy is doing? That guy is squeezing her ass!
Oh, well...

Oh well! What do you mean Oh well?! The guy is actually... He did it again! That's what he's doing... He... He's reaching in, John, to her --! I'll kill him! I'm gonna kill him right now. VINCE marches up and taps FRED on the shoulder. FRED rele MARSHA. MARSHA waits, one hand on her hip, while the two them exchange words. VINCE turns MARSHA, points to her as FRED turns MARSHA, pints to the small of her back. VINCE hopping up and down now. So is FRED. MARSHA, who is getti bored, points to the door. VINCE and FRED bang out. As so as they have gone MARSHA is taken by someone else who put his hand right back where FRED had it.
NICK, SAL and MERLE are standing together, looking at the SERGEANT.
Nick, he just came back.
From Nam?
Fucking A. See that ribbon in the left. That's Quan Son. That fucking guy was at Quan Son! MERLE gestures with his head. NICK and SAL cross with him the SERGEANT.
We, ah... We're going too. The SERGEANT looks at them and delivers a big, blank smil
Pow!
What? The SERGEANT keeps smiling.
(to Nick) What'd he say?
Pow.
Pow?
Pow.
Oh. MERLE nods.
(clears his throat) Uh... well, maybe you could tell us how it is over there?
Pow!
Pow?
Pow! MERLE looks at NICK. NICK looks at SAL. They all begin scratching their heads, trying not to laugh.
Well, thanks a lot. They turn away and then, when they are out of earshot, th all break up, howling.
Who the hell is he?
Who the hell knows!
Is he from here?
Hell no!
Well, where's he from?
(in unison) Who the hell knows!
(soberly) Maybe he's lost.
Lost???
(throws up his hands) Well, I don't know!

The GUESTS have formed in a long double line which extend from the dance floor right out into the street. Everyone pretty drunk and they are all armed with streamers and ba of rice. As SAL and ANGELA appear from out of a back room there is a great rowdy CHEER. The MUSICIANS strike up a MARCH. Followed by the MUSICIANS, showered with streamers rice, advice and encouragement, SAL and ANGELA walk the gauntlet toward the street, where a glossy, bright red Pontiac with headers and straight pipes is being revved i series of ear-splitting crescendos.

JOHN, ALBERT, MERLE and VINCENT are standing by the door. Their tuxedos are stained and torn. Their carnations are squashed and their clip-on bow ties are either missing entirely or dangling from the open collars of their shirt VINCE looks the worst, with a black eye and half his pant torn away, and they are all guzzling beer.
Bullshit! That's bullshit!
You wanna bet?
I'll betcha! That's bullshit and I'll betcha! You're fulla shit!
How much? How much do you wanna bet?
Bet him! Bet him, Vince!
I'll betcha! I'll betcha... I'll betcha twenty dollars!
SAL and ANGELA emerge to more CHEERS and a shower of streamers and rice. ANGELA is helped into the Pontiac on right. NICK throws an arm around SAL and walks him around the driver's seat.
Don't worry what it says in the book.
Right.
Just forget that. Forget what it says in the book.
I'm gonna start slow... At the top. Then I'm gonna work down.
Great. That's great.
That's my plan. NICK gives SAL a hug. SAL gets in the car.
See you Monday.
See you Monday.
SAL looks over at ANGELA.

All set, hon? ANGELA nods. SAL puts the car into gear and starts slowly off. Fists pound on the car. Rice and streamers shower do Suddenly, through the front windshield, MERLE appears, st naked, running in front of the car with colored paper streamers floating out from his upraised right hand. For split second SAL cannot believe what he is seeing. He thr a look at ANGELA. ANGELA covers her mouth in amazement an then quickly shifts the hand to cover her eyes.

MERLE weaves down the street in front of the growling red Pontiac. MERLE is not just running. He is leaping and bounding, as if released from gravity and entered into a realm of pure ethereal space. NICK, ALBERT, VINCE and JOHN pound down the street behind Pontiac, ALBERT carrying MERLE's clothes.
Look at that! Fuckin' guy! Fuckin' Merle!... Unbelievable!

The road forks, one road going high to a parking area, th other descending to the valley below. MERLE swerves up th incline toward the parking area, while the Pontiac goes straight and disappears down the hill. ALBERT, VINCE and JOHN stagger to a stop, panting helples NICK grabs MERLE's clothes from ALBERT and takes off up t hill.

MERLE stands motionless, looking out across the valley as NICK approaches. The night is brilliantly clear and the f from the mill light up the sky with an eerie glow. NICK comes to a stop a few feet away.
Merle? MERLE turns. His face has a strange, distant look, and he gives NICK an almost feral grin.
You think we'll ever come back?
(startled) From Nam?
Yeah. NICK moves up beside him. He doesn't know what to say.

I love this fuckin' place... That sounds crazy. I know that sounds crazy, but I love this fuckin' place... If anything happens, Nick, don't leave me there. I mean it. Don't leave me... You gotta promise, Nick. You gotta promise me that.
(half laughing) Merle --
Promise! You gotta promise!
You got it. MERLE lets out his breath. It is as if some great weight been pressing on him.
(with a laugh) Let's go huntin'. I mean let's do it!
NICK'S battered old shark-finned Cadillac comes screaming past.
NICK, MERLE, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN, all of them still in tuxedos, are jammed in the car between knapsacks, sleepin bags, six packs of beer and deer rifles.
(singing) Let me be free! Let me be free! If... you... will let me be free... You'll... always be happy... with me-e-e-e!!!
(making a trumpet sound) Wa-wa-wa!... Waaaaa!!!
Tale Cadillac comes blasting by...
NICK is hunched over the wheel, his eyes gone completely glassy. MERLE and VINCE are on the nod, while ALBERT and JOHN, both half asleep, are having a lead-voiced conversation.
She fucked you?
She fucked me.
She fucked me too.
She fucked you?
She fucked me too. There is a long pause. They both struggle to keep their e open.
She fucked us both.
Yeah.
Fucking women, man...
(shakes his head) I know...

NICK'S head is sunk below the upper rim of the steering wheel. One eye is entirely shut and the open one seems cl to death. Suddenly his head snaps up. He slams his foot d on the brake and the Cadillac fishtails, rubber screaming a jolting stop. EVERYONE in the car comes awake ten bleary eyes staring o through the windshield. There are deer in the road, fifteen or twenty of them standing in the headlights.
VINCE, ALBERT, NICK and JOHN pile out with their rifles. VINCE immediately slips and falls down.
Get 'em! For Christ sake, get 'em!
Who's got the ammo?
Ammo! Get the ammo!
I'll get it! Where is it?
It's in the trunk!... It's in the trunk! I'm telling you, it's in the trunk! VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN rush around to the trunk. ALBERT begins pounding on it.

There, Albert! Hit it there! Pushing and shoving each other, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN ru around to the side of the car. As they pass along the embankment at the side of the road there is a soft sound, like a sigh, and all three of them simultaneously vanish. NICK, who has been watching, stares at the place where hi three friends disappeared. He takes a few steps forward, realizes what has happened and doubles up in the middle o the road, helpless with laughter.
(getting out of the car) Man, let's go hunting!... Where are they? NICK makes a gesture, a downward pointing of his finger. VINCE crosses to the side of the road.
The slope is a good 45 plus. At the bottom, barely visibl three tiny figures flop in the snow.

VINCE looks down at the three hunters with an expression absolute disgust. He looks at NICK -- flat on his back, pounding his feet, howling -- and then he looks at the de The deer are still watching. If anything they have edged closer and their massed expression of polite curiosity th VINCE into a blind rage.
Get out of here, damn you! Go home!... Scat!... Shoo! VINCE, whose rifle is fully loaded, slams a shell into th chamber and lets off a barrage of shots above the deer.
Bastards! Assholes! Get lost!
The sky is cold -- first light -- with low, wind-driven clouds. CAMERA TILTS DOWN and we see NICK's Cadillac comi up a narrow road flanked by precipitous, heavily forested ridges on both sides.
The Cadillac seems minuscule, overwhelmed by the massive, black slopes looming up from the road.

Everyone is eating cold hot dogs, ripping them out of a h dozen plastic packages, dipping them in a jar of mustard stuffing them down. Hot dog juice has dripped over everything, potato chips are littered everywhere and both beer and milk are being passed around.
Fuel up. Need fuel.
Those are mine!
You want 'em?
Damn right!
Gimme a Hostess Twinkie, Merle.
Here's a Hershey. ALBERT tears off the wrapper, dips it in the mustard and glomps it down.
That's mustard!
(mouth jammed full) What?
You just put mustard on your Hershey bar.
(nods) Good... Pass the beer.
(pointing to a location beside the road) Here, here! This is it!
(milk slopping over him) Watch it, shithead!
(pounds Nick on the shoulder) Here! This is it!
It is not!
It is too! Now you passed it!
It's ahead, by the tree.
It's ahead, Vince.
That isn't it! There's no way that's it... Unless they changed it. They might have changed it. NICK pulls to a stop on the shoulder.
They changed it. That's what they did. This is it but they changed it.
The sky is just turning grey. A cold wind is blowing, moa in the trees and swirling a fine haze of snow across the roadway. The guys all pile out in their wrecked tuxedos.
This is it. Definitely. This is it, but they changed it.
You're full of shit.
Who's full of shit?
You're full of shit!
I'm telling you, they changed it!
They did not!
They did too!

Jesus, it's freezing! NICK, MERLE and JOHN have the trunk open and are taking s out. MERLE strips down where he stands and begins putting his hunting clothes. ALBERT and VINCE grab their things a follow the example of NICK and JOHN, who are changing on corner of the seats.
Whee-uu!
Jesus!
Holy shit!
Merle, hey Merle, you got any socks? MERLE, who is crouched down studying the hillside, looks over.

(rummaging around in the mess of things he has brought) Never mind, Merle. Never mind, I got 'em... Where the hell are my pants? Anyone see my pants?... Who the hell took my pants! VINCE begins plunging around.
Fuckhead! Watch it!
Somebody took my pants... I know I brought pants. VINCE tears into another pile of equipment, comes up with nothing and steps out of the car.
All right. All right, you guys. Whoever took my pants, I want 'em back!

Shots are ringing out in the hills. NICK, ALBERT and JOHN stand by the roadside while VINCE and MERLE glare at each other. VINCE is still in his tuxedo pants, is still weari his dress shoes and is draped in a gigantic red goose dow vest that could only have come from ALBERT. MERLE's knaps lies on the ground in front of him and we can see that it contains a pair of Vibram-soled mountain boots.
Sure I got boots. I got boots right here.
Then lemme have 'em.
No.
(both hands in the air) No!!!?
No.
What do you mean, no???
That's it. No. No way.
Some fuckin' friend... You're some fuckin' friend, Merle!

You gotta learn, Vince! You come out here... You got no jacket, you got no pants, you got no knife and you got no boots. You think everyone's gonna take care of you! That's what you always think, but this time you're wrong. This time you're on your own!
Merle, give him the boots.
No. No boots. No nothin'.
You're one fuckin' bastard, Merle. You know that? You're one fucking bastard!
(snapping it out, jabbing his finger at the ground) This is this, Vince. This isn't something else. This is this!

You know what I think? There's times I think you're a goddamn faggot!... I fixed you up a million times, Merle! (to the others) I fixed him up a million times! I don't know how many times I fixed him up... and nothin' ever happens... Zilch! Zero!... The trouble with you, Merle, no one knows what you're talking about! "This is this"? What does that mean, "this is this"? I mean is that some faggot bullshit, or is that some faggot bullshit!!! And if it isn't, what the hell is it???
Vince. Hey, you guys --
(hopping now) Take last night...! Last night he coulda had twenty fuckin' deer! More! He coulda had more! And look what he does! I mean look what he fuckin' does!!!
Vince!!! JOHN throws up his hands in a comical way.
I'll get the boots.
(in agreement) Get the boots.

(crossing to Merle's knapsack) I mean let's get going before -- MERLE -- who has remained completely calm throughout VINC tirade -- pumps a shell in the chamber of his rifle. JOHN freezes in his tracks and stares at him, his face gone wh

I said no. JOHN looks at ALBERT, who is right behind him, and they b back away. VINCE, who is standing directly opposite MERLE begins to tremble. His mouth comes open, closes and comes open again. Urine begins trickling out from the bottom of pants leg, staining the snow. Suddenly, NICK steps forwar He looks at MERLE, crosses to the knapsack, takes out the boots, walks over to VINCE and throws them on the road.
(gently, to Merle) Let's hunt.

The place is about nine-by-twelve. The floor is rotted ou boards are missing from the walls and the entire structur canted to the right. Hanging from the roof peak is a hiss Coleman lantern which sways in the wind. VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN are sacked out, sound asleep. Beer cans -- some old, some new -- litter the floor. Wet cloth most of them bloody, hang from tie-boards and nails. Stru up on the end wall are two deer carcasses, one of them wi knife jammed in it where steaks have been cut out. Snow is blowing in -- dry, crystal bright. It swirls over everything and settles on the sleeping figures on the flo CAMERA DISCOVERS MERLE AND NICK. They are both in sleepin bags, lying on rusted bedsprings at either side of the br door. The wind gusts and moans. The cabin shudders and th there is a sudden lull.
Hey, Nick?
Huh?
Tomorrow I go with Vince.
Hunt with Vince?
Yeah... I mean so he knows... He doesn't even know.

Traffic is heavy, an unending flow of cars, a river of headlights suspended on a curved concrete trestle which s to float in thin air. Behind is the mill, belching steam ablaze with fire. NICK's Cadillac appears, horn blaring, weaving through th traffic. The car sits low. Trussed to the hood, to the ro to the trunk, are the carcasses of five deer. Rope-ends flutter and bang in the wind. The car shudders and thuds. Inside, grinning maniacally, NICK, MERLE, VINCE, ALBERT a JOHN are all shouting and guzzling beer.

The Caddy appears, swerving onto Columbine with tires screaming and NICK still leaning on the horn. The guys ar all hanging out the windows, shouting to FRIENDS, whistli at GIRLS and banging a triumphant tatoo on the doors.
Maxie! Hey Maxie wha'd'ya say!
Hey Geraldine, let's eat!

Nothin' to it, asshole! Piece o' fuckin' cake! As the car ascends the grade the mill appears behind it, seeming to loom upward under the pink-streaked twilight s CAMERA HOLDS AS THE CAR COMES TOWARD IT. The headlights b white, like huge hungry stars, and the eyes of the dead d on the fenders glitter gold and green and red. ALBERT leans out the window and gives his Tarzan call...

head_text.subj: SEEMS TO ECHO, AS IF COMING FROM FAR AWAY,

text: The leaf is being eaten by an exotic-looking insect. Afte each bite, the insect lifts its head, produces an exceedi thoughtful expression, and chews.

head_text.subj: WE HEAR THE BUZZ AND CREAK OF OTHER INSECTS, THEN A DULL,
FLUTTERING DRONE. THE DRONE GROWS LOUDER...

text: There are twenty of them, coming fast and low, just over tops of the trees. Sunlight gleams on their paint and murderous-looking rockets are packed to their bellies in clusters, like eggs. Suddenly, in unison, they fire the rockets.
As the rockets streak away the lightened choppers shoot upward, lost to sight. There is an eerie silence and then hillside explodes, vanishes in a sheet of smoke and flame miles wide.

A platoon of AMERICANS have been ambushed on the road. Th bodies lie helter-skelter -- headless, armless, legless, spilled in the dirt. No one moves and there is absolute silence except for the low buzz of flies. A V.C. LIEUTENANT steps into sight. He gives a brusque command and V.C. SOLDIERS step out of the jungle. The LIEUTENANT bayonets a few of the fallen U.S. SOLDIERS -- idly, without much interest -- and then cracks a joke as rubs his finger in the Americans' blood. The V.C. SOLDIER laugh, spear a few AMERICANS themselves and repeat the jo There is a slight sound. The V.C. LIEUTENANT spins and gi a low command. Fifty feet away there are three grass huts He signals his SOLDIERS to spread out and then he starts toward them.

South Vietnamese VILLAGERS -- women, children, and a few men -- sit huddled in the semi-darkness. The WOMEN hold t hands over their BABIES' mouths. Flies buzz and there is look of stark terror in their faces.

One of the fallen AMERICANS moves. CAMERA CLOSES ON THE SOLDIER. His face is in the dirt and flies are nuzzling a gash in his temple. The face is unshaven, frighteningly gaunt, but we recognize that it is MERLE. A WOMAN'S SCREAM comes from the direction of the huts. A rings out. MERLE pulls himself to his hands and knees and stands there, on all fours, like a dog.

The V.C. roust the VILLAGERS from their huts, smashing th in the back with rifle butts. One of the SOLDIERS emerges from a hut carrying two small BABIES upside-down by their feet. One of the WOMEN cries out. The SOLDIER gives her a kick, swings one of her BABIES in the air and lets it go. BABY turns over and over against the blue sky. As the BAB comes down ANOTHER SOLDIER catches it through the neck on end of his bayonet.

MERLE strips a B.A.R. from one of his dead companions, sl a fresh clip in it, jams two extras in his pants and star for the grass huts. His movements are slow, almost dreaml and his face is expressionless, like someone risen from t dead.

The VILLAGERS -- about twenty of them -- have been formed a line. As the SOLDIERS look on the V.C. LIEUTENANT walks and down trying to extract information. The SPEARED BABY in the dust between the two groups. The SECOND BABY tries play with it. The SOLDIER who threw the dead baby in the squats nearby and yawns.

MERLE approaches between the huts. He takes a quick look around the corner, finds the V.C. all bunched in a neat package and draws back. CAMERA CLOSES ON MERLE'S EYES. They are cold, dreaming things, glittering blankly.
MERLE spins out with the B.A.R. on full automatic. The V. SOLDIERS go down screaming, arms and necks thrown back, i thin mist of spraying blood.

head_text.subj: ABOVE THE CHATTER OF MERLE'S B.A.R. WE HEAR A GROWING ROA

text: There are five of them, coming in low under the tops of nearby trees.
The VILLAGERS stand motionless, staring at the helicopter and frozen with terror. They turn. They start to run. And then they disappear in a roaring wall of burning napalm.

MERLE stands alone with his B.A.R. surrounded by clouds o billowing black smoke. There is no sound but the rush of heated air and the faint crackle of flames. MERLE'S cloth are burning. Flames are licking up his trouser legs and a blob of napalm is burning fiercely on his helmet. In front of MERLE the SOLDIERS and the VILLAGERS lie in t charred heaps. The BABIES lie between them. Both are motionless now, like two roasted stones. An AMERICAN LIEUTENANT steps out from behind one of the burning huts. MERLE and the LIEUTENANT spin on each other then the LIEUTENANT lowers his carbine.
What the hell are you doing here?
(numb) Saving lives. MORE AMERICANS appear, some twenty of them, coming out of trees in a long line. Among them are NICK and SAL.
Move it out, girls! Move it out! The LIEUTENANT heads down the line. NICK stares at MERLE.
Merle?... Jesus, Merle! MERLE turns and looks at NICK. There is no recognition. H seems to be looking right through him. SAL comes up behind NICK.

Hey...! Hey, Merle! A shot rings out. The LIEUTENANT goes down and suddenly t whole line of AMERICANS is caught in a murderous cross-fi Grenades rain out of the trees. MERLE, NICK and SAL dive cover. Out of the smoke V.C. SOLDIERS begin to appear, more and of them, swarming out of the jungle in scores.

We are looking at the ground where three pits have been d and fitted with bamboo gratings which are held down by stones. The ground is ankle-deep in running mud and the p are filled with water to within a foot of the bamboo gratings. In each of the pits are about a half-dozen men SOUTH VIETNAMESE and AMERICAN. Their hands grip the grati and their eyes are hollow. Other than an occasional groan there is only the sound of the falling rain. A V.C. SOLDIER trudges out of the jungle. As he reaches t pits he notices the hands, curses and begins jumping up a down on the bamboo gratings. The hands disappear. As soon one comes back, the SOLDIER stomps on it, shrieking with laughter. Then, almost as an afterthought, the SOLDIER pu down his pants and squats above the center grating. CAMERA TILTS SLOWLY UPWARD. We see the clearing in its totality. It is a raw hole hacked out of the jungle and contains only two structures. One is a large bamboo "tige cage" with a few leaves tied to its top. The other is a s hut with a thatched roof. The walls of the hut are open a we can see V.C. GUARDS moving about inside. A cry comes from the hut. There is the THUD of a rifle bu on flesh and the cry abruptly stops.

In the middle of the hut is an American kitchen table wit rose-patterned plastic top. At opposite ends of the table two chairs. A SOUTH VIETNAMESE PRISONER sits in one of th chairs. In the other chair, facing him, is MERLE. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE has a welt on his head and one of th half-dozen V.C. GUARDS in the hut is screaming at him. In middle of the table, between the SOUTH VIETNAMESE and MER is a single-action .45 caliber revolver with an American eagle carved on its ivory grip. MERLE sits quietly, waiting, but his eyes are working, ta in every detail of the scene. The V.C. GUARD gives the SO VIETNAMESE a final cuff, takes up the revolver with a dramatic flourish and loads one cartridge into the chambe Immediately the OTHER GUARDS begin placing bets. The GUAR are a ragged bunch -- wet, half-drunk on captured Budweis and it takes some time to straighten things out. MERLE looks off to his right:

We see more SOUTH VIETNAMESE and AMERICAN prisoners stand against the wall. Most of them have been badly beaten and have their elbows tied behind their backs. In among them, standing beside one another, are NICK and SAL. NICK looks grey, like a skinny ghost. SAL is out of control, sobbing quietly.

The betting is now completed. The V.C. in charge waves th .45 around and calls for silence. Then, closing the cylin containing the single bullet, he points the revolver at t ceiling and clicks through the empty chambers until the revolver goes off with a ROAR. Bits of thatch flutter dow from the ceiling. The V.C. GUARDS shout enthusiastically grin. MERLE sits motionless. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE across the ta from him begins shaking uncontrollably. The V.C. in charge now reloads the revolver with one cartridge, snaps the cylinder shut, puts the gun on the t between MERLE and the SOUTH VIETNAMESE and gives it a goo spin. The revolver slows and finally comes to a stop pointing a MERLE. MERLE stares at it for a long beat. Then he picks up, spins the cylinder, cocks it, puts it to his temple a pulls the trigger. The hammer falls on an empty chamber w a loud CLICK. MERLE places the revolver back on the table and pushes it toward the SOUTH VIETNAMESE. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE begins tremble again. Fumbling horribly he finally manages to ge the gun in his hand. He spins the cylinder, cocks the ham and puts the gun to his temple. The gun weaves around. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE closes his eyes and pulls the trigge There is a loud CLICK. MERLE takes the revolver again. He spins it, cocks it -- in one smooth motion -- puts it to his temple and pulls t trigger. There is another CLICK. MERLE pushes the gun back across the table. This time the SOUTH VIETNAMESE takes it up with sudden confidence. He s the cylinder, cocks it, puts it to his temple and pulls o the trigger.

head_text.subj: THERE IS A ROAR. THE PISTOL IS FLYING IN THE AIR AND THEN
MAN'S HEAD, HALF-EXPLODED, CRASHES OVER ONTO THE KITCHEN

text: MERLE doesn't even blink. The GUARDS begin hooting and laughing, wiping pieces of brain from their clothes, and MERLE watches them, watches every gesture, every movement like a cat.
A pile of bodies lie by the steps in the pouring rain. Th bodies are both SOUTH VIETNAMESE and AMERICAN. Their head are all variously blown to pieces and SEVERAL HUGE RATS a already feeding on them.

NICK is at the table now, opposite a SOUTH VIETNAMESE. He holds the pistol by his chin, spins the cylinder. His fac twitching, dripping sweat and both he and his opponent ar holding onto each other's eyes as if they had been at it a long time. NICK raises the pistol to his temple, CLICKS OUT. The GUA murmur. NICK pushes the pistol across the table.

There are no Americans left to play except SAL. The sobbi has stopped but SAL is shaking and trembling and his eyes wander around in their sockets as if they been cut loose. MERLE, who lies on the floor nearby, is trying to talk to SAL. As he does so we hear the CLICKS coming from across room and the excited MURMURS of the GUARDS as their betti choice survives another round.
You can do it, Sal.
No. No, no.
Sal... listen to me, Sal! You have to do it.
I want to go home, Merle.
You have to think about this, Sal. Listen to me, Sal! You have to think about this.
(tears again) This is horrible!
Listen to me, Sal. If you don't do it they'll put you in the pit. If they put you in the pit, Sal, you're gonna die... Sal, do you understand?

(nods) Merle, I wanna go home! There is an EXPLOSION from the other end of the room. SAL eyes go wide and he lets out a whimpering SCREAM. The GUA open a path and NICK appears. His knees won't support him the GUARD who is holding him throws him on the floor.
Listen to me, Sal. Do it! You have to do it! The GUARD who delivered NICK jerks SAL to his feet and dr him of f to the table.
SAL is thrown in the chair. A SOUTH VIETNAMESE is placed opposite him. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE is a kid, even younger than SAL, and he is trembling with terror.

Hey, listen, you can do it.  (Sal nods, smiles) Believe me, you can do it. We can both do it. Then we go home, see? Then we go home! SAL looks down. The pistol is ending its spin and the muz comes up pointing at the SOUTH VIETNAMESE. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE stares at the gun and tears begin to fill his eyes. The GUARDS begin yelling at him, urging him on and SAL gives him a SMILE OF SUCH UNWAVERING FAITH that the S VIETNAMESE picks up the gun, fumbles the cylinder around, cocks it and puts it to his temple. For a moment SAL and SOUTH VIETNAMESE look at each other. THE SOUTH VIETNAMESE

head_text.subj: TAKING HIS FAITH STRAIGHT OUT OF SAL'S EYES AND NOW SAL G

text: The SOUTH VIETNAMESE BOY squeezes the trigger. THERE IS A EXPLOSION AND HIS HEAD DISINTEGRATES WITH A ROAR. SAL sits motionless, his jaw hanging open and his face fo in an expression of terrible puzzlement. Then his face be to move, begins to twitch, as if the muscles were trying discover a frown. SAL looks around. He looks back again a the place where his friend was sitting and he begins to c

A half-dozen SOUTH VIETNAMESE sit huddled together in the muck on the uphill side. A seventh lies sprawled on his b DEAD. The rain pours through the few leaves placed on the roof and splashes in great cascades in the middle of the floor. On the downhill side are SAL, NICK and MERLE. SAL is in a fetal position, gripping his knees and rocking himself ba and forth. His eyes are vacant and his face is fixed in a expression of horror, as if he were still watching the bo the table blow himself away. Beside SAL is NICK. NICK sit slumped against the bamboo. One knee is raised and he is picking at the threads of his trousers where they have to at the knee.

head_text.subj: MERLE IS STANDING, GRIPPING THE BAMBOO WALLS OF THE CAGE

text: The pits are about twenty feet away. Running mud and wate gurgle into them, coming out through shallow trenches on downhill side. There are fewer hands than the day before, fewer. The nearest pit only has one pair and as MERLE wat he sees that these hands are struggling to keep their gri

head_text.subj: SUDDENLY ONE OF THE HANDS SLIPS AWAY. THE HAND COMES BACK
A MOMENT, THEN BOTH HANDS DISAPPEAR.

text: MERLE turns away from the "pits". He looks down at SAL, t he looks at NICK. His expression is one of exasperation, if he had been having a long argument.
I'm telling you, Nick, no one's going to come.
What are you, God?
Listen, asshole, it's up to us!
They bombed last night, right? Didn't they bomb? If they bombed last night, they could bomb tonight. They could be up there right now!
What are you, hoping?
What else?
I thought you might be praying.
I'm doing that too.
I suppose you wish you were somewhere else?
What do you think?
Nick, you're wasting your time... Listen to me! You're wasting your time! This is no fucking time for hoping or praying or wishing or any other shit! This is it. Here we are... And we gotta get out!
You're right... Okay, you're right.
(grabs him) Get off your ass, Nick. Get off your fucking ass and stand up!!!
(stands) Okay, okay! (he straightens his shoulders) Okay. Okay, you're right... What about Sal?
Forget Sal.
What do you mean?
I mean forget Sal... Sal can't take it, Nick.
Forget Sal?
Forget Sal... Listen to me -- forget Sal! I've been working on Sal since dawn, Nick. Sal's in a dream and he won't come out. LISTEN!!! From here on you gotta go for you. You hear me? For you!
Merle...

head_text.subj: HEAD OR YOU AND ME ARE BOTH DEAD

text: A shout comes from the thatched hut. The SOUTH VIETNAMESE whip around in fright. MERLE and NICK turn. Through the bars of the "tiger cage" we see the V.C. GUAR coming down from the thatched hut. The GUARDS are all drinking beer again and the GUARD IN CHARGE is waving the pearl-handled revolver. NICK looks at MERLE. The sight has totally unnerved him.
(calm) We gotta play with more bullets.
We what?
We gotta play with more bullets, Nick. It's the only way.
More bullets in the gun?
(even) More bullets in the gun... The trouble is that still leaves one of us with his hands tied up, so that means we gotta play each other.
(numb) With more bullets?... Against each other?... Are you crazy!!! Are you fucking nuts!!!
Nick... NICK!!! It's the only chance we've got! NICK stares at MERLE. Rain is pouring off them in rivulet and the VOICES of the approaching GUARDS are getting loud
How many bullets?
(watching him) Three bullets -- minimum.
(panic) No way. No fucking way!
(evenly, holding him with his eyes) I'll pick the moment, Nick. The game goes on until I move. When I start shooting, go for the nearest guard and get his gun.
No. No way!
When you get the AK, open up. You got me? Open up.
(screaming)

The GUARDS begin screaming orders from outside the cage a ONE OF THEM lets off a blast of automatic rifle fire whic shreds the bamboo roof just above the PRISONERS' heads. N and MERLE grab SAL and drag him to the door.

As the PRISONERS emerge from the "tiger cage" the GUARDS smash them with their rifle butts, screaming orders. In t melee SAL is separated from NICK and MERLE, both of whom knocked to the ground by furious blows. When they get to their feet they see that SAL is wandering off alone in th direction of the "pits". One of the GUARDS spots SAL and clubs him down. SAL gets up and begins wandering off again. The GUARD clu him down again, turns to the GUARD IN CHARGE and begins complaining. The GUARD IN CHARGE dispatches a SECOND GUAR help the FIRST and the TWO GUARDS open the bamboo grating one of the "pits". MERLE turns to NICK, who is standing beside him.
It's up to you, Nick. Now it's up to you.

SAL has absolutely no comprehension of what is about to happen to him. His eyes are dreamy, far away, as if he ha mentally transported himself to some distant place. Who here is for Merle...? There is absolute silence now except for the drumming of rain. It is as if the war had disappeared, vanished. The GUARDS stand motionless, hardly breathing, so captivated MERLE'S performance that they suddenly resemble little children.

At the sam time NICK throws himself into the GUARD who is standing behind him, spins and slams the GUARD'S AK 47 into his ch TWO MORE SHOTS BLAST OUT FROM MERLE'S .45 and we see TWO GUARDS crash over the kitchen table. text: MERLE has dragged SAL from the car and thrown him in the ditch below NICK. SAL is horribly burned and MERLE kneels over him -- out of breath, tears streaming from his caver eyes -- howling with helpless rage.

REFUGEES are streaming down the road in a desperate, frightened human torrent. There is every imaginable means conveyance -- from bullock carts to motorbikes -- but the vast majority, carrying their meager belongings, are flee on foot. The burned-out car is still in the middle of the road and the great human tide streams around it, as if it were an island. In the distance comes the sound of machin gun fire and mortars are coming in nearby. MEDVAC helicop clatter overhead with wounded strapped to baskets on the skids. Now and then an ARMY CONVOY comes through, blastin the REFUGEES into the ditch. MERLE sits alone on the embankment by the side of the roa NICK and SAL are gone and the area is littered with fresh bandage packages and throw-away medical supplies. Suddenl jeep pulls up with a two-star GENERAL in it.
Where's your unit, soldier? MERLE stares at the GENERAL -- blankly, without comprehension. Finally, after a long moment, he gives a slight shrug.
(to his DRIVER) C'mon. We'll take him along. The GENERAL and the DRIVER get out and start up the embankment toward MERLE.
Little R and R and you'll be standing tall again, son... Damn, this is steep!
Uh-oh. Sir. The GENERAL looks up at MERLE. MERLE is holding the pearl handled revolver and he cocks the hammer with an audible click.
Uh-oh. The GENERAL and the DRIVER turn tail, scramble back down embankment and pile in the jeep.

(as they take off) Y'know, there's more fucking maniacs coming out of this conflict... MERLE watches them go without expression. On the road bel the REFUGEES stream past -- by the hundreds, by the thousands, by the tens of thousands. For a long moment ME watches, then he jams the gun in his pants and stands.
MERLE is walking with the fleeing REFUGEES. CAMERA PANS, HOLDING ON MERLE as he grows smaller and smaller -- to a speck in the vast human torrent.

The room is tiny, a cubicle furnished with a chair. NICK alone, standing at the window looking out. He wears ill fitting civilian clothes whose colors are too bright for- pallor of his skin. Around his neck is a piece of plastic which is stapled a colored paper marker. Departing aircra thunder overhead and there is the sound of some nearby hydraulic mechanism.

Black BODY BAGS are laid out in countless rows on the hot concrete TWO PFC's are stacking them on pallets and MORE PFC's, driving hydraulic LIFTERS, are loading the pallets into the cavernous hold of a huge JET TRANSPORT.
NICK turns away from the window and sits down in the chai Suddenly the door bursts open and a harassed DOCTOR comes
Is your name Solomon? NICK shakes his head.
Are you sure? NICK nods.
Lemme see this. The DOCTOR looks at the paper marker on NICK's neck.
Is this yours? NICK nods.

This isn't yours. This can't be yours! I'm going to take this one off and cut it up... (he extracts a pair of scissors and does so) Shred it... so no one gets a hold of it. What I'm going to do now, I'm going to give you this one. (he staples a new marker around NICK's neck) There. How's that? Does that feel better? NICK nods. The DOCTOR directs a finger at him.

That one's yours. The DOCTOR slams back out the door. Another jet thunders overhead. The hydraulic LIFTERS on the loading ramp shrie and whine... NICK reaches for the new paper marker on his neck and pee down at it from the corner of his eye. It seems to remind of something and he takes out his wallet. In his wallet i PHOTOGRAPH of LINDA. NICK peers at the photograph intentl then closes his wallet and puts it away.

Banks of telephones line the wall. Stretching out from th telephones are long, ragged lines of SERVICEMEN waiting t call home. The room is huge, full of echoes. Re-enlistmen posters are plastered everywhere and CANNED LATIN MUSIC i playing. NICK stands in one of the lines with only one person in f of him. He looks anxious. He takes out his wallet again, peers intently at LINDA'S PHOTOGRAPH, then puts it back. NICK takes a half-step forward -- staring at the telephon and then he stops, frozen with fear.
Go on, babe. Take it. 'S all yours!
(mumbles) You go ahead. CAMERA HOLDS ON NICK as he turns out of the line and head for the exit under a long row of CLOCKS.

NICK comes along the sidewalk in a CROWD OF PEDESTRIANS. is drunk and he moves aimlessly, as if he had been drifti along for hours. (calling) Sal...! Sal!!! NICK throws himself into the traffic, headlong, without e looking. Vehicles swerve and screech to a stop. NICK dodges betwee them, gains the sidewalk on the other side and claps his on the back of a passing SOLDIER. The SOLDIER turns. It i not SAL at all and the resemblance is not even close.

Sorry... Thought you were someone else. The SOLDIER continues on his way. The CROWD streams on, a of bobbing, brilliant color. NICK gropes in his pocket an produces another pint bottle. He unscrews the cap and dow long swallow.

The place is very dark. LOUD MUSIC is playing. Partially- BAR GIRLS are dancing with the CUSTOMERS, while above, on kind of trapeze, NAKED GIRLS are performing obscene contortions. NICK sits at one of the tables. By now he is very drunk a BAR GIRL is giving him her undivided attention.
I love Linda, see. I love Linda more than I can even say.
Everybody love Linda.

I love Linda. Myself, I love Linda so much!

(in his ear) How you like to have nice fuck with Linda? You like that? Special, crazy fuck just like with Linda?

I show you. Come. You come.  (pulls him to his feet) Linda have special, crazy fuck. That right? NICK nods. He looks as if he might be about to cry.

The BAR GIRL comes around the corner with NICK, guiding h to a flight of narrow stairs. She has one hand around his waist and the other down the front of his pants.
You like to call me Linda now?
Linda, yeah.
You call me Linda, just like home. Suddenly NICK draws to a stop, staring at a small window the end of the corridor. He tears himself loose from the GIRL and pushes up against the glass.

Seated on the sidewalk against the wall of the opposite building is an OLD MAN surrounded by a collection of whit ceramic elephants. A truck roars by in front of him. Hey... Hey, elephants! Look at those elephants! The BAR GIRL stares at him.
Linda loves elephants! Linda... she loves 'em! NICK turns and charges back down the corridor with the BA GIRL hot on his tail.
Wait! First I give you special fuck!
Elephants! Make way... I gotta get elephants!
NICK paces up and down in front of the OLD MAN and his ceramic elephants.

Great... These are great. I wanna tell you these are great elephants! I'm going home, see... Stateside in a few days and my wife Linda, she loves elephants. She... she has a thing for elephants because elephants... Elephants go on. You know what I mean? They go right on. I don't know if they cry. Maybe at night. I mean... What I mean is my two best buddies are dead, see, MIA, who knows, and they would have liked some elephants also because... How much are these elephants? I mean let's talk elephant. (notices a GROUP OF STREET

Hey you guys...! Over here! Come over here and carry elephants! The STREET URCHINS come running. They are ragged, malnourished, ranging in age from about six to nine. They covered with sores. One of them ~as lost an eye and anoth has lost a hand.

Everyone take an elephant! (to the YOUNGEST URCHIN) You know how to carry an elephant? (the URCHIN nods) That's what I thought. Right off I figured you as that kind of guy. Hey, wait a minute, I gotta get change. Take an elephant! Everyone take an elephant and then form up. Right here. Over here, like this, in a nice long elephant line... Good. That's good. Man, look at all these elephants! One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten... eleven elephants! (surveys them) Hey, but you gotta stand tall to carry elephants. (he illustrates) Better. That's better. I mean... God damn, I mean that's elephants now! Wait. Now you wait while I get change. NICK dives into a nearby bar.

The place is as dark as the one before. MUSIC BLASTS from jukebox and two vaseline-covered GIRLS are dancing. As NI crosses to the bar to get change there is a WHISTLING SCR and then the FRONT WALL OF THE BUILDING DISINTEGRATES IN ROAR OF NOISE. NICK pulls himself out of the debris. There is absolute silence in the WRECKED BAR but rockets are coming in all the city and the EXPLOSIONS rumble and roar.

A nearby building is burning fiercely. The street is dese except for the sprawled CORPSES of the STREET URCHINS whi lie this way and that, like broken dolls. NICK walks out past the CORPSES. The street is littered w fragments of broken ceramic -- gleaming, pure white, like chunks of snow.
The sky is alight with fires. Now and then HUGE EXPLOSION rock the night and SIRENS wail. A lone figure appears, walking down the middle of the str As the figure approaches we see that it is NICK.

(toneless, over and over) Hey, hey, the wind does blow.  Hey, hey, the snow does snow.  Hey, hey, the rain does rain... NICK swallows, as if to force back some overwhelming emot Then, squatting down under a lamp post, he begins again.

Hey, hey, the wind does blow. Hey, hey, the snow does snow... NICK takes out his wallet, opens it hurriedly to the PHOTOGRAPH OF LINDA and peers at it with a kind of feroci determination, as if this link were the last, as if by staring at it hard he could make it hold.

(his voice thin, cracking) Hey, hey, the wind does blow. Hey, hey, the snow does snow -- There is the sharp report of a pistol SHOT and then, as N spins, staring at a shuttered building, there is the unmistakable sound of APPLAUSE. NICK stares at the building for a long moment, then he crosses toward it.

A tiny light glows inside a paper lantern. Lying on the around are three CORPSES, all of them Asian, all of them expensively dressed and all of them with their heads blow off. As NICK stands looking at them a door comes open on back of the building,and TWO BURLY MEN bring out another corpse. The body is that of a young American. Like the As he is expensively dressed and he is dead from a bullet in right temple.

If you are brave and lucky I can make you rich. NICK turns. A MAN is standing in the shadows of a small g arbor, eyeing him with a look of cold amusement. The MAN' accent is French. Beside him, on a small white table, is bottle of champagne and several glasses.
You have played? NICK stares at the MAN, nods.
Once you have played it is not so hard. Cigarette? NICK shakes his head.
You seem... disturbed.
I... No. You do this for money?

Mais certainment... A great deal of money. Naturally I do not do it myself. I myself do not possess the nerve. (smiles) But I am always... how do you say... looking out for those who do... It is a thing quite rare. Champagne perhaps? Tch, tch. Don't say no. When a man says no to champagne, he says no to life and that no man must ever do. (gives NICK a glass) Where did you play?
Up north.
Ah yes. Of course... So few survive. (smiles) La creme de la creme... How did you obtain release?
Playing.
(raises his eyebrows) Playing?
We... Three bullets.
And then you... The MAN makes a clicking sound, three times, as if firing pistol. NICK nods.
How extremely clever. That is really most extraordinaire... Allow me please to introduce myself. I am Armand... And you are?
Nick.

Nick. C'est extraordinaire! Do you know that I have a cousin who is called Nicholas and a nephew Nickolai. So you are, comme on dit, en famille. In the family. There is another SHOT from inside and another round of APPLAUSE.
I have to go.
But you must come in.
No, I --
But I insist.
I have to go.
You are frightened, no? NICK nods.

Of what is there to be afraid? The war? The war is no problem. It is a joke, a silly thing. I make one call and get you out. ARMAND refills NICK's glass. NICK looks at it. The glass as thin as paper and the sparkling bubbles dance and hiss NICK lifts the glass and empties in one swallow.
See, I'm going home.
Ah yes. Of course. (smiles) To the girl who waits.
(gives him a look and sits) Yeah... Do you mind if I sit?
But of course! Please make yourself comfortable. Perhaps you would enjoy some fresh caviar, or une petite glace, or --?
(weary, shaking his head) No. None of that.
Unfortunately I must now go in, but I leave you my card. Naturellement I pay my players cash American. Just so you know. ARMAND disappears in the darkness. Then his VOICE comes again.

However, should you prefer German marks, or perhaps Swiss francs, this of course can be arranged. Everything can be arranged. ARMAND moves around the side of the building and the soun his FOOTSTEPS fades away. The TWO BURLY MEN come lurching with another CORPSE. Laughter comes from inside the build and there is a glimpse of AN ELEGANTLY DRESSED WOMAN seat at a cafe table. The BURLY MEN return to the door and shu tight. Whadda welcome! Will you lookit... Whadda welcome! NICK stares at the approaching trailer.
That's not it.
What're you, crazy? That's not it??? You said a trailer. You said--

Hey, now listen. Now you said --

LINDA is outside, standing with VINCE and ALBERT.
This is him. I'm telling you, this is Nick! The TAXICAB comes thudding by. LINDA, VINCE and ALBERT al watch as it disappears over a rise.
(to VINCE) I thought that was it.
So he's in the next one, Albert. I mean take it easy. I mean you're driving everybody nuts!
(singing raggedly) Three cheers for the red, white and blue...!
(to LINDA) You okay? LINDA gives a thin smile.
It's gonna be the next one. Okay? LINDA nods.
It's gotta be the next one. I mean it's gotta be! Right, Albert?
Fuckin' A. It's gotta!
It's gotta!
A huge neon sign stands against the grey sky, buzzing angrily, as if it were full of bees. The TAXI DRIVER comes out of one of the units, gets back his cab and pulls away.

NICK stands in the doorway where the driver has left him. duffle bag and the cartons of electric appliances are pil along the wall by his feet. His head is thrown back and h draining a bottle of whiskey, gulping it down in great ra swallows. . NICK lowers the bottle, catches his breath and goes at it again. This time, as he lowers the bottle, the stark pani gone, but there is still fear -- blind, nameless fear, li that of an animal run to the ground. NICK crosses to the window, grips the frame with both han and looks out.

The banner stretching to the house across the street has whipped to shreds by the wind. In the yard, parked beside NICK's black Cadillac, is another car of about the same vintage.
