TWO OLDER WOMEN emerge, putting on their co and then LINDA comes to the door and tells the STEELWORKE she has no news. The STEELWORKERS and the OLDER WOMEN sta off, but now one of the WOMEN points to the frosted up ca The STEELWORKERS go back, pound on the roof of the froste car, pull open a few doors and go on their way. First thi out is a GIRL. Next thing out is a SECOND GIRL. Their dre are rumpled and half-undone. Neither one has a coat and t SECOND GIRL is missing a shoe. The GIRLS both plunge back inside the car, where howling and cursing can now be hear The GIRLS both retrieve their coats. The SECOND GIRL gets missing shoe, plus a bra and a pair of panties. She returns the panties to the FIRST GIRL, puts on her sh and they both take off at a fast trot. As the two GIRLS l there is a cascade of empty beer cans and ALBERT, VINCE a JOHN all stagger out -- bleary-eyed, hung-over, half undressed and freezing. LINDA comes out of the trailer wi coffee, but just as she emerges the whistle at the mill g off. ALBERT and VINCE begin yelling at each other, yellin JOHN and yelling at LINDA. Then they throw themselves bac the car and start off. The case of beer on the roof crash to the street. They stop, pile out, pick up the cans, hea them in the back seat and take off again. JOHN says something to LINDA and goes on his way. LINDA stands in the yard, alone, with the three cups of coffee.
NICK stands half-way down a rickety wooden stairway, watching.
LINDA turns and goes back inside the trailer.

NICK swallows and starts down the stairway toward the trailer. He hesitates, pulls the bottle from his pocket, drains the last of it and tucks it under the stairs. Straightening up, he claws at his hair, trying to comb it with his fingers. Then he starts down again.

Cakes, cookies, six-packs of beer and bottles of wine cov almost every inch of available space. LINDA sits on the little settee, wedged between two cases of Coca-Cola and hunched over a white sweater which she is attempting, wit painful slowness, to knit. LINDA is trying not to cry. Sh trying her God-damnedest. There is a knock at the door. LINDA freezes. Then, trying be totally matter-of-fact, she puts down the sweater, cro to the door and opens it.
Guess who. LINDA stares at him. NICK gives a little laugh and steps
(throws herself in his arms) Nick! Oh, Nick, you're back! She hugs him for a moment, as hard as she can, then they apart.
I thought... Oh, Nick, I thought you were hurt, some accident. Maybe you fell or maybe some car... (back in his arms) I thought someone stole you away!
No.
Oh, Nick! Oh I missed you so! They pull apart.
How are you?
Fine. I'm fine. How are you?
Fine. I just go along, you know. Down at the market. Back here. I mean it just seems there's a million things to do!... Are you sure you're all right? I mean, what about the wound?
(anger) That was nothing. That wasn't anything.
But --
It was just the complications. I mean, you take a little thing over there and then you get complications. I mean all the guys had it.
I made you a sweater.  (she gets it) Here... You have to take that off. NICK removes his coat. LINDA pulls the sweater over him
I couldn't remember your exact size. The sweater is huge, a great rumpled thing reaching almos NICK's knees.

(smoothly) Oh, that's fine. Perfect... It is a little too big...  (she pulls the sweater back off) ... but I can easily fix that. Easily. One thing about wool sweaters, they are such a cinch to fix. She crosses to a garbage pail out of NICK's line of sight stuffs the sweater in it.
How's the trailer?
Great. Fine... Once or twice it did fall off the blocks. I don't know what that's from.
Frost.
Is that what it is? I couldn't figure out.
Did you get hurt? You didn't get hurt?

Oh, no. It just kind of goes thump. Would you like a Coke? You don't drink Coke. Or maybe you do. What about champagne? Let's have champagne! I don't think we have champagne. Let's have this. See? Sparkling. I'll get you an opener. Oh, that's right. No opener. Let's just have beer. Do you want some cheese? Or maybe eggs? Maybe we should have coffee. She begins to sob. CAMERA CLOSES ON HER FACE:
Nick? I'm so glad you're alive! I'm so happy! I... I just don't know what to do!

NICK and LINDA are some distance away. NICK is shaking ha with an ENTHUSIASTIC MAN while LINDA stands to one side, watching his face, and so full of love that she seems abo to burst. ANOTHER MAN comes over. LINDA takes the MAN's a and presents him to NICK.

head_text.subj: WE CANNOT HEAR WHAT IS BEING SAID. THE ONLY SOUND COMES F
THE MILL WHICH LOOMS UP BEHIND THEM OUT THE FROZEN VALLEY

text: NICK and LINDA sit opposite one another. Across the stree coal train is rumbling slowly by and NICK is watching it. cars are black, interchangable, and they roll on and on. Suddenly the last car appears. The car passes and there i silence. LINDA gives NICK a smile.

It was all for nothing. Do you know that? It was all for nothing. LINDA stares at him. She doesn't know what to say, how to respond. NICK forces a grin, gestures with his hand and shrugs. He picks up the check, stands.
Nick?... I just want to say how sorry I am about Sal and about Merle. How... I know you loved them and I know it's not the same. I mean now.
Naw, it's... I mean...
Maybe... I don't know, if you want to talk --
Naw, it's... This guy wants his money.

The place is full of crates and boxes. ONE CREW is unload a tractor-trailer. ANOTHER CREW is stacking and unpacking NICK stands with LINDA and a red-faced, cigar-chewing MAN who is pumping NICK's hand, slapping him on the back and shouting orders all at the same time.

You did a good job, kid. Pettrucio, here! You did a good job. Gimme a count on these pears! I think we got 'em now, know what I mean? The pears, the pears! Ask me, we got 'em right by the balls, know what I mean? Have a cigar. The pears, Pettrucio, the pears!!! He goes off.
(to Linda) Does this... I mean, how does this job work out?
Oh, it's great. Fine. NICK nods. A STOCK BOY comes by and whistles.
Hi you, hot lips.
What do they... bother you!?
(takes his arm, laughs) No-o-o!
I'll kill 'em. Anybody bothers you, I'll kill 'em!
(gently) Nick. It's okay... It's okay. (gives him a squeeze, kisses him) I have to go now. NICK nods.
Pick me up at eight. NICK nods again. LINDA hurries off. The MANAGER comes in behind, clapping NICK on the shoulder and going for his e
That's one sweet little piece of ass. I'm telling you, that's one sweet little piece of ass. Who's got these pears, God damn it! Who's got the count on these goddamn pears!

NICK stands by the entrance to the mill. It is cold and h looks as if he had been waiting for some time. Suddenly STEELWORKERS begin streaming out the doors, heading for t cars. NICK cranes his neck and then he catches sight of ALBERT and VINCE.
Hey, Albert! ALBERT turns. He grabs VINCE and pulls him through the departing STEELWORKERS.
What the --!
It's Nick!
Nick...? (sees him) Jesus, Nick! VINCE grabs NICK's hand, shakes it. Then ALBERT does the same.
Where the hell were you? We were all set -- beer, broads. Right? Am I right?
Yeah.
I got delayed. I --
(hugs him) Hey, Nick! God damn!... What've you been doin', I mean...
Fuckin' guy's been shooting slants, Albert! I mean, what do you think?
I know, but...
What do you think? You think he's been picking flowers? Fuckin' guy's been saving your ass, Albert. Everybody's ass! Even in Europe!
Yeah. Oh, boy, yeah... Jes', you must be tired.
I'm fine. Hey, I'm fine. THEY start for the cars.
How're you guys... I mean, how've you guys been?
Same old thing. Hey, same like always. Nothing's changed. Albert is getting fat.
Look who's talkin'! Jes'! He got married! Vince got married!
Married?
Tell him, Vince.
Yeah. I did. Yeah...What the hell. VINCE makes a gesture, shrugs.
(after a beat) Well, who'd you get married to?
Aw, it's a long story!
Tell him, Vince!
Well... you remember Cynthia?
Cynthia! Sure.
(nods) That's who.
(fast recovery) Cynthia! Hey, that's terrific. I mean... Great! That's really great!
Show him the gun. Hey, show him the gun, Vince. VINCE looks around. Cars are streaming out of the lot, ho blaring. VINCE pulls back his coat and shows a .38 Smith Weston in a holster on his hip.
What the hell's that for?
What's it for??
He's serious. Vince is fuckin' serious!
You mean...?
Hey, Nick, I mean... This here is for the guy that gets caught!
Vince thinks... you know...
(nods) Hey... hey, let's drink!

NICK comes through the CROWD OF STEELWORKERS shaking hand The STEELWORKERS treat him with immense respect. There ar cracks; there are no jokes. They squeeze his shoulder, pa his back, reaching out for him, touching him.

Nice going! Good going, Nick! You did good, boy; you did fine! Let him through! Damn good, boy! Let him through! He's all right! Did his part and he did it good! Let him through! Let's make a little room! JOHN pushes out of the crowd.
Nick! Hey, Nick! (gives him a big hug) Boy! Boy oh boy! Are you okay? You're okay, huh?
Fine. Hey, I'm fine.
Sit down. Here. Right here. (calls) Albert! Vince! JOHN pushes them all into a booth. A tray arrives loaded beer and shots of whiskey.
Here. Here we go. (he raises a beer) Here's to you, Nick!
Fuckin' A!
(stands) Here's to Nick, you guys. He did his part. He did... what hadda be done... and so he did it... and here he is!!!

NICK sits at the bar flanked by VINCE and ALBERT. Both VI and ALBERT are completely glassed out. Behind, in the boo three or four STEELWORKERS are sleeping. JOHN moves aroun behind the counter wiping things off.
Rough, huh?
Rough. (he nods) We didn't have to do it, John.
No?
No. How's Angela? How's she taking it?
Not so good.
No?
Worse since she talked to him.
(with a dull beery blink) Fucking A.
Worse since she talked to who?
Sal.
Talked to Sal? (stares at him) Sal's alive?
Kind of. You didn't know?
(pushes off the counter) Sal's alive??? JOHN, ALBERT and VINCE exchange glances, nod.
He's real bad, Nick.
(stares at them) Well, where the hell is he!!! I mean what are we all sitting here for!!! (tears begin streaming down his face)
Nick...
Hey, Nick...
Nick, we don't know where Sal is... Nick, Angela won't tell us.
Why?... What do you mean?... Why???
Nick, she won't say why.
But Sal's mother! What about Sal's mother!
She's out of her tree, Nick. She is straight out of her tree.
(stares at them) Oh, Jesus. He walks in a circle and then stops, staring at them.
Oh, Jesus!!! NICK turns and goes out.

The room is very dark. ANGELA sits at a lace-covered tabl the window where a street lamp illuminates her in an eeri glow. ANGELA holds a portable radio in tier hand, a very one, and she fiddles with the dial, going from one statio another. There is a sound from the hallway, then SAL'S MOTHER come with NICK.
I know I know you. So familiar. Such a familiar face. Oh, I know now! The toaster man! I'll go and get it for you. SAL'S MOTHER goes out. ANGELA lights up a cigarette.
You're back.
Yeah.
I'm glad. Seriously... I'm very glad.
Angela, I just heard Sal was alive.
Sure. Why not.
Where? Where is he?
Nick, he's fine. He's in a hospital and they're fixing him up.
You talk to him?
Oh, sure... Twice a day.
What hospital is he in? Where?
Nick... Sal is very weak. He suffered a severe wound... and right now he doesn't want a whole lot of people to get involved in a whole thing.
Hey, Angela, Sal and I go back a long way.

He doesn't want people bugging him, Nick! ANGELA begins to tremble, jabs out her cigarette and stan up. She stares at NICK for a moment, goes to a telephone pad writes down a number in a tiny, nearly illegible scrawl. comes up behind her. ANGELA finishes, puts down the pen a stands with her back against the wall. NICK tears off the piece of paper, looks at it, puts it in his pocket.
Angela...? ANGELA laughs and gives a strange, twisted smile, avoidin NICK's eyes.
Did you ever think life would turn out like this?
No.
You know what Sal's got now?... Sal's got... one arm, Nick, and... that's it. The door to the kitchen bangs open and SAL'S MOTHER comes with an electric toaster and a screwdriver.
Here. This is it. What you do, you stick this in here. Pushes the toaster in NICK's arms.
Then you jab it, see. Jab it good. Something's in it. Hear? Listen. Something's in it. What? What's there?

NICK sits on the steps with the toaster that Sal's mother gave him in his lap. It is snowing and from inside the ch we hear the CHOIR SINGING. The sound is massive, deep and dark, like a great river rolling through the night. CAMERA CLOSES ON NICK. He is staring at something, tears glistening in his eyes.
We see a lone telephone booth at the curb. The door is ha open and snow is blowing in.
NICK closes his eyes, leans his head forward and takes it his hands.
LINDA steps out of the shower and begins to dry herself.

It just seems sort of strange coming to a motel... Like a honeymoon. Or some kind of parlez vous ... Not parlez-vous! (she giggles) What am I saying? That's those cocktails! Parlez-vous!... What I mean is rendezvous. Some kind of rendezvous. LINDA pulls on a short and very sexy nightie, then looks herself in the mirror. She is very excited, very nervous. strikes a pose, pulling up the bottom of the nightie and poking a finger in her mouth.
Do you know what I mean?... Nick? NICK doesn't answer. LINDA pulls the door full open, take one last look at herself and goes out.
As LINDA comes out of the bathroom her face falls and she stops dead in her tracks. NICK is lying on the bed -- sprawled on his back, one sho off and sound asleep.
Nick? NICK doesn't stir, doesn't budge. LINDA crosses and looks him -- hungrily, top to bottom -- then she gives his toe wistful shake.

Nick...? Nick, it's me! But NICK is out, gone. LINDA lets out a little moan and s down on the chair beside the bed. Then, almost immediatel she stands and begins taking off his clothes. She takes o his shoes, then both socks. As she goes to undo his belt, shirt, which is unbuttoned, falls slightly open, revealin fresh scar. LINDA stares at the scar for a moment, then s slowly exposes the whole of NICK's chest.

head_text.subj: NICK'S CHEST IS COVERED WITH A SERIES OF TERRIFYING FRESH
STUDDED WITH ANGRY SUTURE MARKS, LIKE A TOPOGRAPHICAL MAP

text: NICK stands at the handle of a long metal rod. At the oth end of the rod ALBERT and VINCE are attaching metallic strips. When ALBERT and VINCE have secured the strips the signal to NICK and all three of them lower their goggles. CAMERA PULLS SLOWLY BACK. NICK is standing below a furnac which is seven stories high, towering above him into a ma of cat-walks and monstrous steel-hipped cranes. ALBERT and VINCE give a signal and the CRANE OPERATOR rai the door at the bottom of the furnace. NICK is now alone, standing like Don Quixote with his lance. As NICK advance toward the base of the furnace with his rod the surface o his asbestos suit begins to smoke and bits of lint which stuck to it burst into flame. Within reach of the furnace now, NICK pauses. Then, lifting the metal rod, he jams it through the open doorway at the base of the furnace. Ther a white flash as the metallic strips explode and then a geyser of molten steel erupts in a huge jet through the doorway, passing NICK at the level of his shoulders and showering him in a great cascade of white sparks.
NICK sits at the bar, silent, hunched over a beer, lost i thought. All around him STEELWORKERS are shouting, yellin cracking jokes. After a moment VINCE pushes in, claps him the back.
How's it feel, huh? How's it feel to be back?
(forced enthusiasm) Great. Feels great... Fuckin' A!
I mean, I guess you still think about Nam. Right? I mean --
Naw. (shakes his head) Uh-huh.
Hey, Nick, you ever do it with one of those slants?
No.
No!
Never one.
Oh, Jesus! (looks around) You're kiddin'!
One, Vince... you have to understand, doing it with one... would be... like nothing. They're small, see, so if you're smart you get about six or eight. I mean, if you want to have any fun.
Six or eight. (nods)  And they go wild?

(lowers his voice) They have these little sticks, Vince. They call them "chomp chomps", and when you get these girls going, you have to stick 'em in their mouths. VINCE stares at NICK. His respiration is up, his mouth is bone dry and his eyes are as big as saucers. For a moment belief is total, then a frown crosses his face.
You're full of shit!
(nods) Yeah.
(pounding him on the head) And I believed you! I oughta punch you out! I oughta...! Hey. Hey, let's go huntin'! Albert! Hey, Albert! Let's go huntin'. What do you say? Nick? What do you say?
Sure.
Hey! Fuckin' A! Hey! He spots JOHN passing with a tray of beer.
Hey, John! ALBERT scoops JOHN into his arms where he holds him from behind.
Yes, Albert?
(into his ear) John,we're going huntin'.
Who's going?
We're all going.
Nick's going?
Nick, Vince, Albert and John.
No women?
No! No women! Jesus! What are you, crazy?
Take these beers. They all take a beer. JOHN raises his glass, solemnly.
Here's to huntin'.
Hey! Fuckin' A!
(hopping up and down) Just like always! Just like it always was! Right, Nick? Am I right?
In the timeless words of Squire Albert... VINCE cracks up, howling.
Squire Albert... VINCE collapses on the floor.
In the timeless words of Squire Albert...
(in a ragged chorus) Hey! Fuckin' A!!!

NICK sits on the bed in the back part of the trailer. His hunting gear is piled on the floor, the lights are out an is staring at the telephone which is illuminated through window by a street light on the corner. There is a sound outside, then the lights come on as LINDA enters with groceries.
Nick?
Right here. LINDA crosses to the doorway.
What are you doing?
Oh. Nothing... Sitting.
You're going hunting?
(blankly) What?
I see you're going hunting. NICK looks at the equipment on the floor.
Yeah... All the guys, we're all going huntin'. Like we did. You know? Like we always used to.
That's wonderful. I think you should... fresh air. NICK gets to his feet, suddenly. His face is twisted with pain and his voice is cracked with emotion.

You know how sometimes you're going along... You're going along... And that's all...! One thing is right after another, like steps... And you step along. NICK can hardly breathe. It is as if he were choking.
I don't know where that is... It's gone! That's gone! A car pulls up outside. The HORN begins blowing, then VIN and ALBERT begin pounding on the wall of the trailer.
Let's go!!!
Hey! Fuckin' A! Time to roll!!!
I gotta go. NICK swings his pack on his back, picks up his rifle and heads for the door. LINDA follows, still clutching her groceries, her emotions so pulverized she can't even spea
I'll be... I don't know... Couple of days.

head_text.subj: NICK IS GONE. LINDA STANDS MOTIONLESS, CLUTCHING HER
GROCERIES, STARING AT THE TRAILER DOOR. IT IS DARK OUTSID

text: Snow is blowing, swirling past the trunks of stark, ice covered trees. There is no horizon. Sky and earth are bou in a moan of wind, in the faint creak of frozen limbs and whispering, fitful, spinning flakes. NICK appears, suddenly, as a gust of wind shifts the slan snow. NICK is moving easily, heading slightly uphill, following the contour of the slope. As he draws closer we that he is following a SET OF FRESH TRACKS.

A magnificent SEVEN POINT BUCK stands by a grove of hemlo looking down the slope. NICK appears below, barely visible in the swirling snow. The BUCK watches NICK for a moment, then turns unhurriedl and vanishes into the trees.

VINCE is out of breath, clawing his way up a steep slope all fours. JOHN and ALBERT, who have reached a level area above VINCE, unsling their rifles. SHOTS are going off in every direction and the sound is so magnified by echoes t it sounds like a full scale war.

What are you, kiddin'? Are you kiddin' me, Albert? Twenty times I coulda had her! She...! One time she begged me, practically begged me. Listen, I had her tit, which was out, in one hand, and my other hand... You know that mole on the inside of her right leg? Well, I was past that mole, way past that mole, and I was -- JOHN nudges ALBERT. FOUR DEER are coming down the slope, single file. JOHN and ALBERT raise their rifles and FIRE. OF THE DEER FALL AND THE REMAINING TAKE OFF. VINCE, who i just getting to his feet, unslings his rifle, trips and f down. JOHN and ALBERT drag VINCE to his feet and then rus over to the TWO DEAD DEER.
(coming after them) Nice shootin', you guys. Not bad. Not half bad. Leans his rifle on the horns of one of the fallen DEER.
'Course how could you miss, right? Twenty, maybe thirty feet. I mean, if I'd'a been where you guys were --

Psst. Vince! JOHN signals with his head. VINCE turns. ANOTHER DEER has come out of the woods. The DEER is rattled by the gunfire peers at VINCE uncertainly. VINCE spins and grabs his gun which immediately goes off. He slams another shell in the chamber and scrambles to his feet but the rifle sling is hooked on the antlers of the DEAD DEER and another shot ricochets off a nearby rock. JOHN and ALBERT dive for cov As they look up, they see the DEER trot down the slope an then VINCE, firing wildly, running after it.

The wind is much stronger, moaning in the trees. NICK appears, moving fast, at a near trot. Suddenly he stops, listening. At the same moment there is a snort. NICK whee The BUCK is behind him, bounding away.

The BUCK appears, trotting out of the swirling snow. Reac a deadfall the BUCK pauses, looking back, and then turns sharp left and disappears. NICK comes out of the snow. He is winded but still going hard.

NICK reaches the deadfall, hesitates, then rapidly spring over. As he touches down on the other side there is a growling sound. NICK grabs for the deadfall. The wind shifts and we see t he has stepped onto a boulder which is loosely planted at top of a steep scree slope. As NICK watches, the boulder begins to roll, then to bound, dislodging other rocks and boulders, all of them bouncing and leaping and cracking.. and then falling -- soundless -- over a sheer ledge to unknown depths below.
ALBERT and JOHN have dragged their TWO DEAD DEER to a log beside the shack. They sit side by side, drenched in swea guzzling beer out of both hands.
Sweet! Oh, that is sweet!

Hey! Fuckin' A! Just... just like a hot shit... except cold. JOHN lowers his beer. ALBERT gives him a blank expression then cracks up. SHOTS explode nearby. At first the shots scattered but they quickly open into a FULL BARRAGE. ALBE and JOHN stand up.

The DEER that VINCE was chasing earlier comes hobbling ou the woods pursued by a GROUP OF HALF-DRUNK HUNTERS. VINCE comes barreling through the HUNTERS, shouting and screami VINCE's clothes are in tatters, the sole is gone from one shoe and the barrel of his rifle is jammed up with mud an perceptibly bent.
I got this one!!! This one's mine!!! VINCE loses his footing and rolls down the embankment, he over heels.

VINCE comes up ten feet from the bewildered DEER. He rais his rifle, fires, and the BARREL SPLITS OPEN. SHOTS begin coming in, thudding in the mud and ricocheting off rocks. DEER wheels out on the highway. VINCE heaves his rifle at DEER, draws his pistol...
Cars are parked on both sides of the road. HUNTERS are sitting in the cars, drinking, eating sandwiches and warm themselves at small fires. MORE HUNTERS are up on the embankment.
I got this one!!! This one's mine!!! The panicked DEER bolts down the highway between the park cars. The HUNTERS ON THE EMBANKMENT open fire. The HUNTER THE CARS dive for cover.

Hold your fire! I got this one!!! VINCE FIRES, FIRES AGAIN. SHOTS are ringing everywhere. HUNTERS are shouting, running, yelling. A car window goes out, a headlight goes out. The DEER is hit, falls and get up. VINCE takes aim. A FLEEING HUNTER bowls him over. The DEER bolts for the woods, bullets smashing all around it. VINCE scrambles to his feet and plunges after it.
I got it! I got this one!
The DEER staggers through the trees, blood pouring from i wounds. VINCE comes stumbling after it. HE FIRES, FIRES AGAIN.

ALBERT and JOHN stand with their beers, looking into the woods. A shot zings by, close, and they dive behind a log The DEER comes out of the woods, barely able to keep movi VINCE appears, reeling. He takes aim at the DEER and ther a DULL CLICK. VINCE jams his pistol back in his holster.
Gun! Gimme gun!!! ALBERT indicates his rifle. VINCE stumbles over to it, ra cartridge in the chamber.
(looks around, bewildered) Where's it gone?
Inside, Vince. VINCE staggers to the cabin door. The DEER is lying on th floor, motionless, DEAD.
I got it! Hey, you guys, I got it!!!

The wind is blowing in gusts, slanting the snow first one and then the other. NICK appears in the distance, a black speck in the endless expanse of shifting white. As NICK draws closer we see that he is near exhaustion. H clothes are , caked with snow, his breath comes in a shal gasp and his gait is uneven, favoring one leg. As NICK APPROACHES CAMERA HE FALTERS AND LIMPS TO A STOP. There a no tracks. There is nothing to go by and he hunkers down the driving snow. The wind bangs in from one way, then it shifts and bangs again from another way. Suddenly it stops entirely. In th silence there is a sound -- the click of a hoof on rock. NICK turns. The BUCK is standing on the shoreline, not th feet away, looking down at him. NICK pushes himself to his feet, raises his rifle and sig down the barrel.

head_text.subj: NICK'S FINGER IS ON THE TRIGGER. HE HAS ONLY TO SQUEEZE I
NICK LOWERS HIS RIFLE. THE BUCK SNORTS, TOSSES HIS HORNS
NICK STANDS MOTIONLESS, STARING AFTER IT, SO WONDER-STRUC

text: (grins) Damn... God damn...

NICK sits on his haunches with his back against a sheer r face. As he devours a Hostess Twinkie he looks out over a snow-shrouded landscape of such spectacular beauty that i might be something from a dream.
(shouts) Hey! Hey... okay!
The Coleman lantern hangs from the rafter, rocking in the wind. NICK is propped against the wall, dozing. JOHN is o cold. ALBERT and VINCE are both drunk and arguing bitterl
You're full of shit, Vince! You're so full of shit you're going to float away!
Who? Who is?
You, Vince! You! You are! You're a crock! You're a walking, talking crock!... I mean, what do you know?
I know! I fuckin' know!
You don't!
I do!!!
I'm tellin' you she does it, Vince! With twenty guys you know!
She does not!
Then what's the gun for! What's this for?
In case!!! The gun's in case!!!
In case???!!! In case of what? In case you stumble on her, suckin' cock in the front fucking hall?!
She might!!! She might do it, Albert, but you can't fuckin' tell me that she does!!!
She does, Vince! That's what I'm telling you! She does!!! VINCE is sheet-white, trembling. He grabs up the pistol a cocks it.

(shrieking) Say that one more time!... Say it!!! Go on, say it!!! NICK is half-way up the wall, still half-asleep, staring the pistol in disbelief. Suddenly he springs, seizes the with one hand and slams VINCE to the floor. VINCE gets up NICK slugs him in the face, knees him in the stomach and begins pounding his head against the wall. ALBERT lurches over, pulls NICK away.
Nick! Nick, you'll kill him!... Easy. Nick, easy! Hey, hey. Vince goes back a long way.
(grimly) Yeah. VINCE gets to his feet. Blood is streaming down his face.
What the hell was that! (picks up the pistol) What did you think? Did you think it was loaded!
You loaded it, Vince! I saw you!
The fuck I did!!!
The fuck you didn't!... Gimme that! NICK takes the pistol.

What do you think? You think I don't know!!! NICK looks at him, then he EMPTIES THE PISTOL INTO THE FL For a moment there is absolute silence. The wind moans in trees, snow curls through the open door and JOHN, who is still soundly sleeping, finds a new note on which to snor NICK looks down at the pistol, turns it over in his hands
I'm going to throw this fuckin' thing away. NICK goes out.

For a moment NICK stands in the light from the door, listening to the wind. He looks down at the pistol again, then he heaves it into the trees. The wind gusts. The snow swirls and hisses, slipping thro the woods in great streaming wraiths. NICK watches it for a moment, then he turns and goes back

The trailer is lonely looking, DARK and cold. VINCE pulls into the yard beside NICK's car and skips to a stop. NICK gets out, says a few words to VINCE and everyone laughs. goes around to the trunk, removes his gear, slams the lid pounds on the car. VINCE takes off, thudding over the cur with his load of THREE DEAD DEER. NICK crosses to the trailer and goes inside.
TWO DOZEN AMPUTEES in wheelchairs are watching a western.

In the foreground a NURSE holds a telephone. Beyond the N we see a wizzened figure in a wheelchair coming slowly do the polished corridor. As the figure draws closer we real it is SAL. SAL is dressed in a white hospital gown, the bottom of which hangs over the front of the wheelchair an trails limply on the floor. Both SAL's legs have been amputated and he has lost one arm. His face is terribly scarred and what expression he displays is centered in hi eyes. SAL takes the telephone. THE SOUNDTRACK FROM THE MOVIE IN RECREATION ROOM IS VERY LOUD.
Hello?
NICK sits in a little chair by the window, still in his hunting clothes, huddled anxiously over the receiver.
Sal? Sal, it's me, Nick.
Nick. Hey. How's things?
Oh. You know. How's it with you?
Same. Hey. Same old stuff.
(he can hardly hear) What's that noise?
What?
What's that noise?
John Wayne... Listen, Nick --
Great. Hey. That's great.
Listen, Nick --
John Wayne's great... Listen, Sal. Jesus. When are you getting out?
I'm gonna stay here, Nick.
(hearing it) What?

(with everything he has) Place is great. Really. One great place... Basketball, bowling. You name it. Canasta. Hearts. Lots of guys are making salad bowls. What I'll do is make a salad bowl for you, unless you'd rather have a pencil holder. The pencil holder's neat, I mean --
Wait a minute. Sal. Hold it. John Wayne's making so much noise I can hardly --
I gotta get back, Nick. SAL looks around in desperation.
They're passing out popcorn now, so I'll be talking to you... maybe next year.
NICK holds the receiver, staring into it. There is the SO OF WHOOPING, GRUNTING, THUNDERING HOOVES...
Sal?... Sal?

SAL is wheeling himself rapidly down the polished corrido At the doorway to the recreation room he pauses, looking at the DANGLING RECEIVER. Then he turns and disappears in the flickering darkness, where BUGLES are sounding a cava charge.

NICK listens to the SOUND OF THE BUGLES for a moment, the puts the receiver back on the telephone. He stands, walks around in a little circle - pained, terribly upset. His e falls on the clock. It is nearly eight o'clock. He turns, hurries out the door.
The lot is empty except for scores of abandoned shopping carts which a CLERK is banging together. NICK gets out of his car and goes in.
Two or three CHECKERS are closing out the registers up fr
She's in back.
Thanks.
How was huntin'?
Oh. Fine.
Get anything?
No.
Too bad. NICK goes down a long aisle of bright packages. Coming ou the back he finds LINDA sitting in a green plastic chair, crying.
Linda... Honey, what's wrong?
(helpless shrug) I don't know.
Hey. Look. There must be something. LINDA looks at him, tears streaming down her face.
I'm just so lonely.
C'mon. I've got the car.
(shakes her head) I'll be out... Just leave me. I'll be out. I'm fine. Really. I'm fine. NICK walks back down the aisle between the bright package

The CLERK is still collecting abandoned shopping carts. T carts crash and clank as the CLERK rams them together. NICK sits behind the wheel, watching the clerk. His hands begin shaking uncontrollably and he gets back out of the
NICK watches the lights go out in the market. LINDA comes of the door and crosses towards him.
You okay? LINDA nods. NICK fumbles for the door.
Let's make love, Nick. LINDA takes him in her arms and holds him tight.
Let's make love forever!

LINDA is asleep - lying on her back, arms flung out acros the pillows, like a dancer leaping. NICK stands beside the bed, wrapped in a blanket, looking down at her. After a moment he draws the covers over her, fusses with her slippers until they are straight and then goes to the window.

location: STREET IN FRONT OF NICK'S TRAILER, (NICK'S POV)

text: The wind is blowing. Bits of trash skitter and swirl in t frozen ruts and a cat comes by, MEOWING. Suddenly a MAN appears walking slowly down the street. The MAN is elegan dressed in Western attire, wearing a tailored suit with v polished boots and a Stetson hat. As the MAN draws under light of a street lamp he pauses, looking at NICK's trail

head_text.subj: THE MAN IS MERLE, OR IF NOT MERLE IT IS A FACE SO STRIKIN
SIMILAR THAT NICK ALMOST LETS OUT A CRY.
THE MAN UNDER THE STREET LAMP PAUSES, JUST FOR AN INSTANT
THEN HE TURNS AND MOVES ON DOWN THE STREET.

text: NICK backs away from the window. For a moment he stands motionless, hardly able to believe his eyes. He looks ove LINDA, he looks down at a chair, then he pushes his face the window again.
The street is empty. The MAN is gone.
NICK hesitates, then he sheds the blanket and pulls on pa shirt, jacket and jams his sockless feet into a pair of slices.
NICK comes out into the street. There is no one in sight. NICK crosses to the intersection of Columbine.

No one. Nothing. A beer can rolling in the wind. NICK jams himself against a wall, zippers his jacket. He irked with himself, a little frightened. Suddenly he hear car door close and en engine start up. A black limousine pulls out of a nearby street and comes past him slowly. A CHAUFFEUR is at the wheel. The PASSENGER in back appears to be the MAN he saw, but t MAN is looking out the window on the other side and his f is not visible. As NICK watches, the limousine rapidly gathers speed. The tail lights grow small, then the car dips over a hill and disappears.

Sunlight streams through a window. The television is goin In a far corner SAL sits in his wheelchair, sleeping. CAMERA CLOSES SLOWLY ON SAL. His head has fallen to one s and his single arm sticks into the air -- as if he had fa in his grasp of something, as if he were drowning. On a t in front of him is an untouched breakfast of orange juice milk and a little box of Wheaties.

Someone is descending the stairs. After a moment the feet appear, clad in expensive cowboy boots. We see expensive, tailor-made trousers, a belt buckle embossed with a six shooter... and then, suddenly, MERLE'S FACE. MERLE slows in his descent, stops, looking at something.
NICK is getting out of a cab. He pays the driver and star toward the building.
MERLE watches NICK for a moment, his face utterly without expression, then MERLE continues down the stairs.
NICK is pushing SAL down a walkway.
Sal, we need you. We need you.
Hey, Nick. How can you need me?
We do, Sal. We do... You're the heart. Turns SAL and sits on a bench.

Sal, you're gonna die! You're gonna sit in that corner watching soaps and you're gonna die!... I'm not saying it's gonna be the same. It's not gonna be the same, but whatever it's gonna be we're all gonna do it, Sal. God damn it we are! We are gonna do it!
Nick. I'm so scared. I'm so fuckin' scared to go home.
(nods) I know. It's like coming from the moon. Or Mars. SAL laughs.
Did you go hunting.
Yeah.
Did you get one?
No.
You didn't get a deer?
I tracked this one, a big buck. God, he was such a beauty--! What's this suitcase here?
Where?
Here. Behind you. NICK pulls a suitcase off the rack behind SAL's chair.
I don't know. NICK sets the suitcase on a low wall and starts to undo t clasps.
Maybe Angela brought you stuff. I know she said -- The suitcase slips over the back of the wall.
Shit! NICK swings up on the wall and then he freezes. The lid o the suitcase has popped open and bundles of money are scattered all down the slope of a steep embankment.
Mom keeps sending me socks, Nick. I mean, if it's socks or something just let 'em go.
NICK looks down at the money scattered at his feet. The bundles are made up of hundreds and they are everywhere.
Maybe you could use socks, Nick. Jesus, I mean, come to think of it socks are pretty expensive now.

It's not socks, Sal. NICK bends over the suitcase and begins going through loo for identification. There is nothing. As he straightens u notices a wadded-up piece of paper lying beside one of th bundles of bills. The paper is about an inch square. The corners are tatter and it looks as if it had been carried in someone's pocke for a long time. NICK picks the paper up, realizes it is a calling card an unfolds it.

head_text.subj: THE CARD READS "EXHIBITIONS". IT CONTAINS A TELEPHONE NUM
ON THE LOWER LEFT CORNER AND IS IDENTICAL TO THE CARD ARM
GAVE TO NICK WHEN HE CAME UPON HIM IN THE GARDEN BEHIND H

text: NICK leans on a railing watching the black, interchangeab cars of a coal train roll slowly by. SAL sits with the suitcase of money in his lap, utterly bewildered, crying.
Who is it, Nick? Who is it? I don't understand. NICK looks at SAL. His head is spinning and he brings him back with effort.
It's Merle, Sal.
Merle? ... Merle's alive? (NICK nods) How do you know?
I saw him last night. I thought I was dreaming. I thought I was out of my mind.
Merle gave me this?
Yeah.

But, Nick... Hey, I mean, where would a guy like Merle get money like this? NICK is standing slightly behind SAL, looking down at the money. The reality of what MERLE is doing, has nearly overwhelmed him and it is only with tremendous effort tha maintains a casual tone.
Oh cards, maybe. Poker... It's getting cold, Sal. I'm going to take you in. (starts off) We'll call Angela. The guys can help her bring you home... Did I tell you I was going on a trip?
(panicked) Trip? What do you mean, Nick? You said you'd be --
It's okay. Hey, it's okay! Just a week. Just to see Phantom Mary.
Phantom Mary?
Didn't I ever tell you about Phantom Mary?
(laughs) No.
(starts off again) Well... Phantom Mary's on my mother's side. Naturally no one there admits it because Phantom Mary's pretty weird... You want to hear the whole story?
(enthusiastically) Yeah!

Like I say, Phantom Mary's pretty weird... Lives alone, lives way out in the middle of nowhere with a cat called Pajamas and a cow called Fred. Well, last week I got a call from Phantom Mary, which in itself was very strange...

The place is a madhouse of activity. As jets scream overh TROOPS embarking for Saigon are being counted and recount SERGEANTS are yelling off names. CLERKS are typing forms papers. Forklift trucks weave in and out, DRIVERS cursing NICK is back in uniform. He stands at a window watching a transport being prepared for loading. A CLERK comes by, arguing with a SERGEANT. The CLERK sets down his clipboar consult the SERGEANT's papers. NICK picks up the clipboar and moves into the CROWD.

NICK spots a lone SECOND LIEUTENANT sitting on his gear. OFFICERS are waiting nearby but the SECOND LIEUTENANT see not to know them. NICK moves in close enough to read the SECOND LIEUTENANT' name tag.
(bawling) Biederman! Where's Biederman!
Here.
You Biederman?
Biederman, yes.
I got you on this flight, Biederman. Is that right?
Correct.
Follow me, please.
NICK walks along briskly with the LIEUTENANT at his side.
Right this way.
NICK comes to a door, opens it.
Through here.
The LIEUTENANT walks into the closet and comes to a stop, looking puzzled. NICK comes in behind him, closes the doo and picks up a length of pipe.
Take off the uniform. The LIEUTENANT stares at NICK, dumbfounded.
Take off the uniform, Lieutenant! The LIEUTENANT nods, begins taking off his uniform.
NICK has changed into the LIEUTENANT's uniform and tied h to a chair. The LIEUTENANT is in tears. NICK is going thr his orders.
Please! Please mister, please! This is vital I go to Saigon. This is very important. Most important.
(exasperated) Listen, Biederman, I'm going to club you into the floor unless you tell me what the fuck is so important.
That I must not tell you. Top secret. You see there. Topmost secret.
Biederman!
(stiffly) I will not betray my country. No. Ne-ver! NICK throws down the pipe in disgust, whips a gag around LIEUTENANT's mouth and ties it.
When I get to Saigon I'll tell 'em where you are. Slams the door.

Viet Cong SAPPERS have just attacked. A number of jet fighters are burning, bodies are strewn over the tarmac a jeeps with SOLDIERS are racing back and forth. Out beyond, the jet transport taxis into view, lumbering a great silver monster out of the night.
NICK stands in the aisle next to a COLONEL who is peering the window.
Jesus Christ, they hit the airport! NICK nods.
Those fuckin' niggers. This time I'm going to eat balls!... You ever try 'em?
Naw.
(leans close) Not bad fresh, but they don't keep worth a pig's fart. NICK nods. EVERYONE starts out.
Lotta guys don't know that. (winks) Assholes!
A SIREN is screaming in the distance. NICK looks around nervously. The COLONEL is still right in beside him.

Tell you something else. Don't eat 'em in the damn Delta. Unless you like 'em fishy... Some do. I don't. I never did. The scream of the SIREN grows louder. Suddenly a Jeep car around the corner followed by a huge black Cadillac flyin American flags on the fenders. Both vehicles screech to a stop and an MP jumps out of the jeep with a loud hailer.
(amplified) Lieutenant Biederman! Lieutenant Biederman report to the ramp!
That's you. (grabs NICK's arm and waves) Right here, Sergeant! He's right here!
Right this way, Lieutenant. NICK is hurried to the limousine where a SECOND MP holds door.
Quick as you can, sir. We're in a rush. NICK gets in the limousine. The SECOND MP slams the door, jumps in the front and they take off with sirens wailing.
There are jeeps with MP's ahead; there are jeeps with MP' behind. Seated beside NICK is a gigantic MARINE CORPORAL stares rigidly ahead.
Pedestrians and bicyclists flee as the cavalcade comes screaming down a wide boulevard.
The jeeps peel off to the side. The gate swings open and limousine enters the compound.
A STRING QUARTET is playing. GUESTS in evening clothes ar drinking champagne. NICK enters with the MARINE CORPORAL and is whisked rapid down a hallway.

NICK stands in front of a huge range staring down at a ta On the table there is a basket of eggs, an omelette pan a pile of mushrooms. Across from the table six SERVANTS wit napkins on their arms stand waiting with plates.
Sir? NICK turns. The MARINE CORPORAL is holding a chef's hat. takes off his cap, puts on the chef's hat. Suddenly a doo comes open and the AMERICAN AMBASSADOR and his WIFE come
Henri! So good to see you. How are you? How are you? Darling, this is Henri. Henri, my wife Elizabeth.
My pleasure.
Henri, we are starved. Six omelettes, s'il vous plait.
(hissing) Avec champignons.
Avec champignons. (back to his WIFE) Fines herbes? The WIFE shakes her head. The AMBASSADOR winks.
Avec champignons. The AMBASSADOR and his WIFE hurry out. There is dead sile NICK pulls the MARINE CORPORAL to one side, points to his crotch.
Pee-pee.

NICK comes down the corridor behind the MARINE CORPORAL. he passes a straight-back chair standing against the wall picks it up and swings it down on the MARINE CORPORAL'S h The blow is ferocious. The chair splinters into pieces an the MARINE CORPORAL goes down with a dull thud. NICK stands for a moment, looking at him. Then he kneels, removes his pistol and jams it in his belt.
Three MARINE GUARDS are standing at parade rest by an ope iron gate. As NICK appears in his white chef's hat the GUARDS snap t attention and he walks into the CROWD OF ASIANS streaming outside.
NICK takes out his wallet, extracts the tattered calling that he found with SAL'S money and dials the number. He l it ring a long time but there is no answer.
NICK is not sure where he is. Suddenly he stops, recogniz the yard with the little grape arbor where he met ARMAND.

The yard is grown over. As NICK goes in there comes a low buzz of flies. He trips over something, draws back. Seein candle on the little table under the grape arbor, he cros and lights it. The yard is full of discarded champagne bottles, red velv cushions and rotting CORPSES. NICK leans over one of the CORPSES. The skin is falling away and the eye sockets wri with maggots. NICK straightens, looks around.
Merle!!! The back door to the building is open. NICK draws his pis and goes in.

NICK finds his way blocked by a door. He steps back, hurl himself against it. The door gives way with a crash and h staggers into the middle of a small stage hung with red velvet curtains and furnished with a table and two chairs Out beyond the proscenium, huddled together in a litter o broken cafe tables, a FAMILY OF REFUGEES stare at him in terror from the other side of a small fire.
(waves pistol) It's okay. The REFUGEES cower back even further.
(screaming) It's okay, God damn it! It's all right! POUNDING and BANGING come from the direction of the front door. NICK crosses...

NICK readies his pistol, cautiously unbolts the door and jerks it open. The COLONEL FROM THE AIRPLANE tumbles in a falls flat on his back. Standing in the doorway, lit by t headlights of two cars, is a party of U.S. OFFICERS, ARVN OFFICERS and WHORES.

(no attempt to get up) Hey, good buddy, how you doin'? (gestures) This is Biederman, you guys. Biederman, this is Son Loc, Tu Fon, Huckerbelly and Potts. What's the story here, Biederman? We're looking for... Wait a minute. He fishes a piece of paper out of his breast pocket.
Here it is. Chez Armand.
Chez Armand not here! Chez Armand has gone to other spot!
(gets up) Honey, c'mere. Come right here. The COLONEL opens a brown paper bag he is carrying and presents her with a large red, white and blue dildo.
This is for bein' so smart. The WHORE shrieks with pleasure. EVERYONE laughs.
(arm around WHORE) Let's go! Mount up! C'mon Biederman! The COLONEL throws an arm around NICK and they all start the cars.
(to NICK) Boy, do I love this conflict. Huh?... What the hell were you doin' in there?
You know a guy named Merle?
Merle? That's who we're looking for. Merle.
Yeah?
Sure! I got eight hundred potatoes says he goes one more... He retired, you know.
Yeah?
Now he's back. Pulls NICK close so he can whisper in his ear.
He eats 'em... Sure... He eats 'em raw!

An elegant house of French design is ablaze with lights. house is encircled by a stone terrace on which tables hav been set up. Over the terrace and strung out for a hundre yards into the surrounding trees are countless paper lant which bob and sway in the wind. GUESTS are everywhere -- wandering in and out of the house, sitting at the tables strolling under the trees. For the most part the GUESTS a AMERICANS and SOUTH VIETNAMESE. The majority of these are OFFICERS IN UNIFORM, but there are numerous CIVILIANS mix among them and the CIVILIANS are attired in everything fr sports shirts to white linen suits and tuxedos. As to nationality there are no limits. There are FRENCH, GERMAN BELGIANS, SWISS, CHINESE, BRITISH and AUSTRALIANS. WHORES MISTRESSES abound. WIVES are not greatly in evidence, exc to dog the heels of heavily armed ARVN GUARDS who wander about, glass-eyed, drinking champagne.

Jeeps, personnel carriers, trucks and light tanks are par side by side with gleaming Mercedes limousines, staff car from various government agencies and a blitz of civilian vehicles running from sedans to motor scooters. More vehicles arrive by the minute and exotic couples, li plumed birds, debark in the swirling dust.

A dozen ARVN helicopters have put down between the trees. has crashed and lies on its side with a broken rotor. There is a mounting clatter in the distance and another helicopter comes out of the sky. As it sets down a dashin handsome AIR FORCE OFFICER hops out and extends a hand to WIFE. When his WIFE has descended the OFFICER opens a bac compartment in the fusilage and carefully takes out their BABY. He hands the BABY to his WIFE and they stroll off toward the house.
Gambling tables are set up in all the rooms. The betting heavy, champagne flows like water and the atmosphere is o of reckless abandon, as if money, like love, were good fo hour.

Low bleachers covered in red velvet are set in a semi-cir facing a small stage. The stage is lit with a single, blindingly bright spotlight and is furnished with a table two velvet-covered chairs. Two CONTESTANTS, both of them VIETNAMESE, sit opposite one another. Between them, lying the table, is a revolver. Both CONTESTANTS are dressed in tuxedos. Both wear red numbers on their downstage arm. Although the bleachers are not yet full, eager BETTORS ja the first three rows. Here CLERKS with change trays take bets, signalling each transaction to a MARKER who chalks shifting odds on a large board. CAMERA CLOSES ON NICK, standing in the aisle, staring in disbelief at the evolution of the game he once played. Now a REFEREE enters the stage carrying two strips of sca cloth.
(amplified) Game number seven. Gentlemen will please wrap. The CONTESTANTS wrap their heads with the scarlet cloth.

(as he loads revolver) One cartridge. Game to be played to completion. Forfeit automatic after delay of one minute. The REFEREE places the pistol back in the center of the t and spins a wheel whose -intervals are alternately marked and R. The wheel clatters to a stop with the marker on L.

Gentleman on the left will now commence play. The REFEREE steps out of the light. A gong sounds. The CONTESTANT on the left picks up the pistol, spins the cylinder, cocks it and places it to his temple. He hesitates, pulls the trigger. and clicks out. NICK is unable to bear it. He turns, starts around toward back of the stage. AS NICK MOVES THROUGH THE GUESTS WE HE THE SOUND OF THE CYLINDER CLICKING, AMPLIFIED OVER A P.A. SYSTEM. WE HEAR THE CLICK OF THE HAMMER BEING COCKED... NICK turns. The SECOND CONTESTANT has the pistol to his temple. He pulls the trigger... THE GUN GOES OFF WITH A DEAFENING ROAR and he topples on the floor. The FIRST CONTESTANT STEPS FORWARD AS THE SPOTLIGHT NARRO

head_text.subj: TO CONTAIN HIM ALONE. HE BOWS, CLASPS HIS HANDS ABOVE HIS

text: NICK stares at the FIRST CONTESTANT celebrating his victo He looks around him. BETTORS are screaming and yelling in five languages. NICK starts off again, hurrying.

NICK comes upon a pile of six naked CORPSES with their he blown off. Opposite the CORPSES -- sitting, standing, pac squatting in the dirt -- are a GROUP OF WAITING CONTESTAN Some of these are AMERICAN. Most are SOUTH VIETNAMESE, several of whom have come with WIVES and FAMILIES. A few the contestants are well dressed, most are in rags. THREE THE WAITING CONTESTANTS ARE WEARING TUXEDOS. Suddenly a WOMAN WITH A BABY lets out a shriek. NICK spin TWO BURLY MEN appear, bringing the CORPSE OF THE SECOND CONTESTANT. As the WOMAN WITH THE BABY begins sobbing and screaming with grief the BURLY MEN strip the tuxedo off t SECOND CONTESTANT and then, as each article is summarily removed, they begin dressing one of the WAITING CONTESTAN in it.
If you are brave and lucky I can make you rich. NICK turns and finds ARMAND behind him. ARMAND studies hi for a fraction of a second and then smiles.
C'est tres amusant... You have been promoted. And to a Jew... I am joking of course. Naturellement. Seriously, Nick, may I hope that you have come to play?
I came to see Merle.
Ah. Merle. And you know Merle?
Yeah.
(studies him) You are his friend.
Where is he???
(faint smile) Merle is under his tree... Beside the terrace. You can't miss him.

GUESTS are still coming in from the cars, strolling down through the trees in bright coveys and flocks, chattering like birds. Laughter comes from the terrace. Glass tinkles and the ti lanterns bob and sway. NICK appears, hurrying down the steps. Suddenly he stops. MERLE is sitting at a table under a nearby tree. He is al dressed in a tuxedo, watching the arriving GUESTS with an expression of dreamy detachment, as if they were rain dro or snow flakes, or falling stones.
(shouts) Merle! MERLE turns, watching NICK as he crosses toward him. When NICK reaches the table, he stands.
Merle...! Jesus! Hey, how are you?
Nick!... I thought you went home.
I did. I... This is stolen. I came back.
Sit down. NICK sits. MERLE's self-possession has thrown him. He doe know where to start.
(breaking the silence) How's Linda?
Fine. She's fine... Merle, what the hell are you doing?
(eyes him) I like it, Nick.
Merle... Hey, Merle, listen...  (stares at him) Why? For a moment MERLE doesn't answer. His eyes are pale, lik faded robin's eggs, and they seem to look through NICK, a to some landscape far beyond.
I like it because it's simple. A BEAUTIFUL VIETNAMESE GIRL steps up and whispers somethi in MERLE's ear.
(stands) I have to go, Nick. We'll have a drink. MERLE and the VIETNAMESE GIRL move into the CROWD.
Merle...! Merle, wait! NICK starts after them. He can see them ahead, moving rap through a GROUP OF ARVN OFFICERS and WHORES.
Merle!!! NICK sees he can never overtake them directly. He cuts ar to the terrace.
NICK maneuvers his way down to the end of the terrace.
Excuse me... Sorry... Sorry... Pardon. NICK reaches the end of the terrace. MERLE and the BEAUTI VIETNAMESE GIRL have disappeared.
NICK sits at one of the tables. The terrace is deserted.
Gentleman on the right will now commence play.
The gaming tables are utterly deserted. AS NICK WANDERS

head_text.subj: THROUGH THE EMPTY ROOMS THE SOUND OF THE GAME CONTINUES O
SOUND OF THE HAMMER BEING COCKED... AND CLICK AFTER CLICK

text: Suddenly NICK can stand it no more. He turns and starts toward the entrance to the bleachers. A SHOT EXPLODES OVER THE P.A. SYSTEM. NICK freezes, then runs.

NICK appears at the back of the aisle between the bleache The CROWD is going wild, yelling and screaming. NICK push through a group of BETTORS and then stops. A look of stun relief spreads over his features. On the stage a tall figure stands alone in the spotlight, head bowed in acknowledgement of the OVATION. NICK grins. He begins yelling and screaming along with everyone else. On the stage the tall figure raises his head, pumps his f in the air and begins hooting maniacally.

head_text.subj: ... WE NOW SEE, AS DOES NICK, THAT THE TALL FIGURE IN THE
SPOTLIGHT IS NOT MERLE AT ALL. IT IS MERLE'S OPPONENT.

text: Pipes crisscross the ceiling and there is the faint hiss leaking steam. Seated on a bench and all dressed-up in th uniforms are FIVE OLD VETS. TWO VETS are on the nod. THE OTHER THREE -- rheumy-eyed and ancient -- give patient attention to the SIXTH VET who stands beside the boiler w a bugle, trying to play TAPS.
Up a little there... What would you say?
Up. The VET WITH THE BUGLE tries it again, flubs it, starts over...

Three tables have been set up in the middle of the floor. tables have been laid with white cloth and the OLDER WOME are setting out fresh flowers and laying the places for a funeral breakfast. They work in silence, fussing over the placement of each knife and fork.

head_text.subj: AS THE WOMEN WORK WE HEAR THE SOUND OF THE CHOIR SINGING
THE SERVICE PROGRESSES IN THE CHURCH. AT FIRST THE SOUND
BARELY AUDIBLE, EASILY MATCHED BY THE FAINT NOTES OF THE
WITH THE BUGLE IN THE BASEMENT BELOW.
BUT NOW THE SOUND OF THE CHOIR GROWS

text: Gradually, one by one, the OLDER WOMEN stop fussing with table. They stand motionless, listening.
A HEARSE waits at the curb. The day is windless, cold and grey Snow is drifting down and the gleaming vehicle emits ghostly cloud of white exhaust.

head_text.subj: THE SOUND OF THE CHOIR IS MUCH LOUDER, ASCENDING IN DARK
TRIUMPH TO A SUDDEN, FINAL NOTE.

text: In the ringing silence of the MUSIC'S END the doors to th church swing open. NICK, VINCE, ALBERT and JOHN appear wi MERLE's flag-draped COFFIN. Followed by MOURNERS, they be the COFFIN slowly down the steps.

Snow drifts down from a leaden sky as the MOURNERS stand together on a steep hillside of tilted, weather-worn headstones. The mill looms behind them, breathing roiling clouds of steam and uttering a dull concordia of clanks a groans.

The PRIEST completes his reading of the 23rd PSALM. The MOURNERS join in the LORD'S PRAYER. CAMERA CLOSES ON NICK, VINCE, ALBERT, JOHN and SAL. They SAL to the side of the grave. It is awkward. The chair ge stuck and they have to carry it. THEY ALL pick up a handf of dirt and then, following NICK's lead, they throw it in NICK steps back from the grave, nods to the VETS. The VET come to attention. The VET WITH THE BUGLE steps forward a tremblingly, but perfectly, PLAYS TAPS.

The meal is over. The WOMEN are drinking coffee, the MEN smoking and putting down the beer. There is muted laughte and conversation. NICK sits at the head of one of the tables, flanked by LI and SAL.
